ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. In general, Western log markets are highly tensioned by available supply, while Southern log markets have more available supply. However, additional mill capacity being added in the U.S.

SECTION 5 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

urn:contentItem:6GJM-8W93-RRT3-33GS-00000-00Fury in Tenerife as travel platform names crowded spot 'most photogenic place' in Spain2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisFury in Tenerife as travel platform names crowded spot 'most photogenic place' in SpainEmily Wright

A travel platform has sparked anger in Tenerife, causing overcrowding fears

A travel platform for campervan travellers has sparked controversy after recommending Tenerife’s Chipeque viewpoint as one of the six most photogenic places in Spain, despite ongoing concerns about overcrowding, safety risks and environmental damage in the area. The company, CamperDays, listed Chipeque, in Tenerife’s Corona Forestal, at number two in a new ranking that also features Galicia’s Playa de las Catedrales, Navarra’s Bardenas Reales, and Setenil de las Bodegas in Cádiz. The site was highlighted for its spectacular views of Mount Teide rising above the clouds below.

While some might assume locals would be grateful for the extra publicity, in recent weeks, Chipeque has become a tinderbox for tourism pressure. Earlier this month, more than 50 people were removed from the viewpoint after authorities closed all access to it due to extreme wildfire risk and scorching temperatures. However, despite he restrictions, images have continued to circulate on social media showing traffic jams, illegal parking and crowds ignoring restrictions.

King Felipe VI and Queen Letizia visited the viewpoint in October 2023 to assess the areas affected

Concern is growing in Tenerife over the influence social media is having on young people's travel choices. A recent study found that 40% of Spanish millennials and Gen Z choose destinations based on social media posts, while 58% prioritise experiences over material goods, Canarian Weekly reported.

data-mce-linkchecker-status="valid"

Critics have argued this trend is fuelling a “perfect storm of mass tourism” in Tenerife’s natural areas. Photographer Diego Manrique has drawn attention to dangerous behaviour being witnessed at the viewpoint, including smoking in pine forests during fire alerts, littering and flying drones illegally.

data-mce-linkchecker-status="valid"

Mirador de Chipeque is located in Santa Ursula, Tenerife, at an elevation of approximately 6,000 feet. It offers panoramic views of Mount Teide, the highest peak in Spain, and the surrounding landscapes, including the La Orotava Valley and the northern coastline of Tenerife. On clear days, visitors can also see the island of La Palma in the distance. The location is also known for its "sea of clouds" phenomenon, where a blanket of clouds covers the valleys below in a surreal scene.

data-mce-linkchecker-status="valid"

The viewpoint is accessible via the TF-24 road, which connects La Esperanza with Teide National Park. King Felipe VI and Queen Letizia visited the viewpoint in October 2023 to assess the areas affected by a severe forest fire

There are strict regulations for motorhomes and campervans within eide National Park and the Corona Forestal

The promotion of Chipeque as a campervan destination is particularly controversial because of the strict regulations for motorhomes and campervans within Teide National Park and the Corona Forestal. According to the rules, parking is only permitted in designated car parks, and the use of awnings, tables, or other camping equipment is forbidden. Overnight stays are not allowed and environmental officers and traffic police can fine for illegal parking, camping, or risky behaviour.

In the first six months of 2025, authorities issued nearly 700 environmental sanctions in Tenerife, many related to improper use of natural spaces.

data-mce-linkchecker-status="valid"

Local organisations concerned with Chipeque viewpoint have stressed the importance of responsible tourism to protect fragile landscapes like this and avoid accidents. Authorities recommend visiting during quieter hours, respecting closures and always using official parking areas.

The Telesforo Bravo–Juan Coello Foundation has also warned that authorities are prioritising tourism over conservation, while the Tenerife Cabildo has insisted it is stepping up enforcement with the Guardia Civil, Policía Canaria and environmental officers. Officials have confirmed that denuncias and fines are being issued to those who ignore closures or park irresponsibly.

urn:contentItem:6GPW-XMW3-RRR5-02TN-00000-00Sask. government paid $100M too much for new firefighting planes, B.C.-based manufacturer says2025-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisMANUFACTURING INDUSTRY NEWS & AEROSPACE AND DEFENSE INDUSTRY NEWSSask. government paid $100M too much for new firefighting planes, B.C.-based manufacturer says

Coulson Aircrane says the Saskatchewan government has agreed to pay more than twice what it should have for four firefighting aircraft - a decision the B.C.-based company says will cost Saskatchewan taxpayers an extra $100 million.

Coulson, one of the leading companies in the world for retrofitting planes for firefighting, made the claim last month in an application to the Court of King's Bench.

"We are concerned the government of Saskatchewan has awarded a very large (over $187,000,000) contract for forest fire airplanes, without affording any reasonable opportunity to Coulson or any other competitor to bid on the contract," says an affidavit filed by company president Britt Coulson.

Coulson is asking the court to quash the sale and order a fair, transparent competition.

In February, cabinet approved the purchase of four Q400 planes, retrofitted for firefighting purposes, from B.C.-based Conair Group, Coulson's chief competitor, for $187,042,000 payable in increments over the next four years. Conair delivered the first plane this summer.

Earlier this year, the Saskatchewan government was being widely criticized during the spring's forest fire crisis because several planes in its fleet were out of service, some because of a lack of parts. The province says the new planes will help Saskatchewan tackle future crises more effectively.

Coulson says his company and Conair "are the only two major suppliers of airtankers globally." In his affidavit, Coulson says his company "likely could have provided Saskatchewan with four comparable airplanes for approximately $85,600,000, saving Saskatchewan more than $100,000,000."

He says the government failed to hold a proper, competitive tendering process, resulting in Conair making "an immense profit."

Coulson says a used Q400 plane can be purchased for about $5 million and can be retrofitted for firefighting for an additional $5 million.

But Conair is charging $46,760,500 per plane.

"Therefore, it is my understanding that Conair stands to profit $36,760,500.00 per plane or $147,042,000.00 in total," Coulson writes.

Conair has declined to comment, as the matter is before the courts.

'A reasonable apprehension of bias'

In the application, the company says it can only think of one explanation for Saskatchewan's "unreasonable" decision - bias.

"A reasonable apprehension of bias is plainly present and offers the only cogent rationale for why a competitive bid process was not followed," Coulson argues.

Coulson points out that Peter Boniface, the executive director of air operations for the Saskatchewan Public Safety Agency (SPSA) and key decision maker on the purchase, was Conair's director of maintenance from 2006 to 2013.

"A governmental employee sole-sourcing a $187,042,000.00 [contract] from their past employer and taking active steps to avoid the standard procurement policies and not exploring cost saving options at all ... creates a clear reasonable apprehension of bias in making the decision," the court application says.

Coulson says the court doesn't have to conclude that this deal was influenced by "nefarious or illegal conduct, such as the presence of bribes or kickbacks," to find there was bias, it merely has to find that the decision maker was "influenced by an extraneous factor such as friendship with Conair employees, directors or owners."

CBC asked the Saskatchewan government about Coulson's allegations, but it didn't respond to the questions, instead issuing a brief statement declining to comment because the matter is before the courts.

However, the government did address some of the issues in court documents.

In an April 17, 2025, email filed in court, the Saskatchewan government told Coulson its procurement process was "fair, open and transparent." It said Coulson's planes were evaluated but they "failed based on size requirements."

Regarding Coulson's allegations of bias, the government said, "The decision to contract with Conair was in no way the result of Peter Boniface's previous employment, but was a result of the Conair product being the only aircraft which could meet the SPSA's reasonable criteria."

Coulson says those criteria are where the problems all began.

Process favoured Conair, Coulson argues

In early 2022, the SPSA hired an independent third party, which the government refuses to name, to look for firefighting planes that met criteria prescribed by the province.

Coulson says the fix was in from the very beginning, because Conair was the only manufacturer that offered planes that met Saskatchewan's criteria.

"The criteria was deliberately designed to influence and restrict the results of the recommendation, so that the report ... would recommend the planes be sourced from Conair," the application says.

The province stipulated that it needed a plane that has a 10,000-litre capacity tank, is capable of speeds greater than 270 knots and has a range of 640 to 700 nautical miles.

Coulson says Conair's planes, "have a top speed of 278 knots and a range of 670 to 700 nautical miles, which are remarkable similar to the [government's] speed and range criteria." In addition, he says Conair is the only manufacturer that sells retrofitted planes with a tank size of exactly 10,000 litres.

Coulson says his planes have a top speed far greater than 270 knots and a range of 2,000 nautical miles, almost three times what is listed in the criteria. In addition, Coulson's tanks are larger than 10,000 litres, coming in at 15,000.

"There is no bona fide reason for the requesting a tank capacity of 10,000 liters as it excludes airplanes which may offer larger capacity tanks," the application says.

"It is obvious that the airplanes manufactured by Coulson offer better performance having larger tanks and better range, at a much lower price than Conair," Coulson adds in his affidavit. 

Does size matter?

Coulson acknowledges his planes do not satisfy the government's size criteria.

The government wants planes with tails no taller than 30 feet, but Coulson's offering is 37 feet, six inches.

In its April 2025 email to Coulson, the province says Coulson's failure to meet the size criteria is why its planes weren't considered, adding "It is unreasonable to expect that, in addition to purchasing aircraft, the SPSA ought to incur further expense to modify its existing infrastructure to accommodate larger aircraft."

The problem with size appears to be related to the height of the tail, Coulson says - that the tail of Coulson's 737 is too high to fit into some government hangers.

But he says this issue is a red herring, as firefighting planes are typically not stored in hangers during fire season. Coulson says they can be stored in any available commercial hanger during the off season, as 737 planes are pretty common.

Also, Coulson says, even if the government wanted to store planes in hangers during the fire season and Coulson's 737 was too big, that is a fixable problem that could have been addressed in a fair, transparent tender process.

"The cost of building new hangars or renovating existing hangars to have seven more feet of clearance would be  substantially less than the approximate $100,000,000.00 of savings the SPSA could have obtained through buying the Coulson 737s instead of the Q400s at the price charged by Conair."

Finally, Coulson says that even if the government was set on buying Q400 planes, he still could have put in a bid.

He says his company's internal analysis shows, "it would be able to produce and sell those planes for a similar price to what Coulson sells the Coulson 737 for, i.e. $21.4 million, if not less."

How the government chose Conair

Coulson says he first heard of this opportunity in late May 2024, weeks after the government had already awarded the $187-million deal to Conair.

Coulson says this caused him "serious concern," because his entire business is built around learning of and bidding on opportunities just like this.

"It would have been the first time Coulson had missed a public competition, to my knowledge."

On June 4, 2024, he reached out directly to Boniface by email to ask how the contract was bid on and awarded.

Boniface replied by saying the province first set criteria for the sorts of planes they needed, then hired a company, by tender, to look for what was available, settling on the Q400 as the best option.

"An Advanced Contract Award notification (ACAN) was publicly posted for 28 days and completed prior to the agency entering negotiations with the selected vendor of the Q400," Boniface wrote.

An ACAN is a public notification that the government intends to sole-source a purchase, giving other vendors the opportunity to argue for a public competition instead.

In its ACAN, posted April 10, 2024, the government said it was planning to purchase four Q400s from Conair because it is "the only supplier that meets SPSA's requirements for this procurement."

The deadline for reply was 14 days later - April 24.

The key details of the purchase had been hammered out and announced publicly weeks before the ACAN was posted.

On March 20, 2025, the province announced news release that it was purchasing four Q400s "for an approximate cost of $187.06 million." In fact, emails obtained by Coulson through an access to information request show that discussions about the proposed transaction with Conair had been ongoing for months.

CBC asked the province why Boniface said Saskatchewan didn't enter negotiations with Conair until after the ACAN's public posting when the deal was actually announced before the ACAN was posted. CBC also asked why Boniface told Coulson the posting was up for 28 days when it was in fact up for just 14.

It didn't reply.  

Coulson says he's never heard of a contract for firefighting planes being awarded through an ACAN, saying it's "the first time I have become aware of a contract being awarded to a competitor in Canada without first being aware of the public competition taking place."

"This was not because we missed it - it was because no public competition took place."

Coulson says he can't help but conclude, "that Conair and SPSA purposefully kept their negotiations private."

He said in every other case he's aware of, governments have gone out of their way to ensure his company is aware of the opportunity to foster competition in this small industry that primarily has just two competitors, Conair and Coulson.

"Typically the party posting the competition will market the competition and make contact directly with Coulson and other suppliers to ensure we are aware of the competition and in order to get as many bids as possible," Coulson said, adding that given his time at Conair, Boniface would have known of this practice.

Coulson says the government's third-party researcher failed to reach out to anyone from his company. In a letter back to Boniface, Coulson expressed surprise at this failure.

"In our experience selling Large Airtankers to Government Agencies, there has always [been] a fair and open competition through a public RFP and to date we have always beat out the Q400 as the best value," Coulson wrote.

Coulson says Saskatchewan's approach of "awarding a fixed price contract directly to a single supplier without first engaging in a public competitive tender process - is a substantial deviation from standard industry practice."

He says it's also a violation of many of Saskatchewan's procurement policies.  

For that reason, among many, Coulson argues the Conair contract should be set aside and a competition should be held.

"The decisions by the SPSA, the Minister, and the Lieutenant Governor to sole source an $187 million contract and not follow any of the above procedures or policies breached the legitimate expectations of Coulson Aircrane."

Province wants case thrown out

In court last week, Coulson argued that the province should hand over all documentation the government considered in making this decision.

The province is refusing, arguing that instead the court should throw out Coulson's application.

The province says Coulson has known about this contract for more than a year and should have brought this application sooner if it really believed it had merit.

In addition, the province says judicial reviews like this are not designed to assess the merits of the government's policy decisions, but only to assess whether the decision-maker had the authority to do what they did.

In other words, the province says, "even if the decision under review is found to be unreasonable or incorrect (which Saskatchewan denies), this court should refuse to grant a remedy," and therefore not hear Coulson's case.

Saskatchewan says a decision to end Conair's contract would be fraught with trouble, given that the company has already delivered its first aircraft.

"Granting of any remedy sought in relation to cancellation of the purchase agreement with Conair would cause substantial hardship and/or substantial prejudice to Saskatchewan which may include hindering Saskatchewan's firefighting efforts," the government said in its written response to Coulson's application.

In court, Coulson's lawyer Reilly Pollard said the government's refusal to provide documentation could lead someone to conclude "they're covering something up," an allegation the government's lawyer quickly disputed.

The case will likely be back in court later this fall.

urn:contentItem:6GN6-HV33-RYKK-C38G-00000-00Thunder Mountain hosts action-packed races2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisSPORTSPg. 12Thunder Mountain hosts action-packed racesRuth Lloyd

Thunder Mountain Speedway’s track saw some action on Aug. 23 with the Memorial Race.

It was a small crowd out to watch the cars, but those who came got a few different special treats, and we’re not referring to the ice cream available on site to help cool the crowd.

The Central Cariboo Search and Rescue team performed a demonstration extraction and drivers pulled up for a meet and greet with spectators, giving them the opportunity to sit behind the wheel of a race car. There were also some crashes, creating some thrilling race action.

It was another tough break for Olivia Finamore, after she was struck by Chip Schick in the hornet class heat.

This was the second time Finamore’s custom paint job was personalized by a fellow racer, and she had to head straight for the pits after this one, with her steering compromised. Initially, Finamore feared she wouldn’t be able to finish the night, but her handy husband and some helpful fellow racers with a key part got her back on the track and ready to go for another round by the end of the meet and greet.

Luckily for Finamore, there was a bit more time to work on her car while Central Cariboo Search and Rescue (CCSAR) completed a demonstration vehicle extraction. Harley Astleford took one for the team by crashing a PT Cruiser into a minivan in the centre of the track. The extraction crew opened up the cruiser’s hood, disconnected power to the vehicle, then exposed and cut away the top of the vehicle, allowing the rescuers to lift the entire roof off and away. They then slid in a spine board to show how they could fully extract the injured person in case of an actual crash.

Another collision happened later in the night’s action-packed events, after the Tribune had left the scene.

A post on the Thunder Mountain Speedway Facebook page by Loren Hollett celebrated the night of action with a shout out to the CCSAR crews and said it was the first night of racing under the new 77Motorsports banner, showing photos of the damage to their car after the night’s events. His son Asher Hollett, the car’s driver, was in a final add-on event, after the main events were done. Having won third in the main event in his class, Asher went for another 25 laps, but lost control at one point.

“The car got a little bit snakey,” said Loren. The car flipped one and a half times, landing on its hood. He said those who left early missed out in catching the crash.

But the roll cage did it’s job and thanks to the extensive safety equipment, Asher himself was apparently none the worse for wear. The same could not be said for his car, and the track tow truck had to give it a little help to get it onto the trailer. Loren said the damage appears to be limited to the front end, and they hope it isn’t anything structural.

Despite the car looking quite crunched, Wayne posted a promise the team plans to make the final race of the season.

“With a lot of blood sweat and perhaps a few expletives, 77 will be at the track for the season-ender September 27,” he wrote. He said the offers of help from the Thunder Mountain community have been amazing.

“It won’t be pretty, but it’ll be up and running,” he said.

Being the Memorial Race, a black flag lap was done to honour the three former Thunder Mountain racers who had died in the past year:Karl Seibert, Don Urquhart, and Earl Thomas.

Racers who took home trophies include:Emily Thomas who won the Hornet class main event and had the fastest time in Hornet class, Sage Howlett who won one for the Hornet Dash event and second in the Hornet main event, Asher Hollett was third in the Hornet class main event, Mikey Garcia clocked the fastest time for the Legends class and won the main event, Jay McKeown was second in Legends main, Dagon Spooner was third in the Legend class main event, Brett Melville was first in the Thunder class dash, won the main event and also had the fastest time in Thunder class and Sheldon Emerson was second in Thunder main.

One of the most exciting parts of the night for some may have been the celebrations after the races when fireworks began nearby at the Dirt Riders Association motorcross track area. But shortly after they began, so did a forest fire.

Those still in the pit area at Thunder Mountain quickly called in the fire with the help of their Starlink connection, as there is no cell service at the Thunder Mountain Speedway or motocross track.

Emergency crews responded and the fire was listed as under control on Monday, Aug. 25.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BNV3-RS5Y-6090-00000-00Feijóo sentences Sánchez's State Pact before it gets off the ground2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisFeijóo sentences Sánchez's State Pact before it gets off the ground


The fire crisis has become one more reason for dispute between the Government and the opposition, amidst the growing citizen's weariness. As already happened during the Dana or the blackout, the reproaches between administrations for the management and responsibility for what happened, have monopolized much of the political statements and media attention. When the flames were still at their peak, Pedro Sánchez offered a State pact for the climate emergency that has yet to materialize .


In the midst of the criticism, the president interrupted his vacation in La Mareta and appeared telematically addressing the situation. He also took off the hook with another measure of an ideological nature, instead of proposing concrete initiatives for the prevention and extinction of fires. He also promised more troops, but days later, the Autonomous Regions were still criticizing the fact that he had not yet arrived.
The worst of the tragedy has passed, although there are still several active outbreaks, the president of the PP has started the political year by putting on the table 50 anti-fire measures that he will take to the Congress of Deputies to be debated by the groups. In parallel, the Executive holds this Tuesday the first meeting of the interministerial commission for the State Pact, a recycled measure that was announced five years ago and has not yet been implemented.
Green policies
The announcement made by Feijóo augurs the failure of a possible agreement between the two major parties, given the permanent refusal of Sánchez to negotiate anything with the PP and his intentions to present the pact of State as one more reason to break with the right that allows, in turn, to agglutinate the partners around his person. An attempt to reassemble the parliamentary majority at a key moment of the legislature, where the lack of Budgets presages a possible electoral advance.
Another reason why the pact is stillborn is the difference in criteria established by both parties when it comes to addressing the causes and solutions to this problem. Sánchez insists on talking about climate change, without further analysis, while Feijóo highlights the responsibility of arsonists, the lack of coordination protocols between administrations and the absence of a list of available means for the Autonomous Regions to act more quickly.
In addition, the PP calls for"encouraging forest management, with support for planning and sustainable use: the forest that is used burns less", something that contradicts the thesis of the Government, which only blames the high temperatures, for which it blames human action, as the cause of the flames. The Popular Party is also committed to"encourage agricultural and livestock practices that contribute to the maintenance of forests and fire prevention in the Strategic Plan of the CAP in Spain".
Cleaning and conservation of the countryside
Among other measures, they also demand"to modify the StateForestry Law, as basic regulations, to make forest exploitation and forest groupings more flexible, the reduction of woody fuels and changes in forest use whose purpose is the prevention and facilitation of forest fire extinction, as long as they remain in the agroforestry area".
Along the same lines, they are in favor of"reviewing and reforming the European regulation that has led to the reduction ofthe forest
has resulted in the reduction of extensive livestock and the cleaning of forests as a complement to the support of the clearing of forests". In other words, a comprehensive review of the current greenpolicies that have damaged the conditions for the prevention and extinction of fires, just the opposite of what the Executive intends to promote.
The State Pact is not even guaranteed the support of Sánchez' s partners , who are no longer willing to grant anything without being paid in advance, and they see the possibility of going to elections ever closer, so they are distancing themselves from the Executive. The same strategy they are carrying out to approve legislative reforms or the PGE.

urn:contentItem:6GRW-S7Y3-RXG1-G33Y-00000-00The unsustainable burden of diabetes and obesity2025-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisThe unsustainable burden of diabetes and obesity


In Mexico, the obesity and diabetes epidemic is no longer just a public health problem: it is an economic and social time bomb that is on the verge of collapsing the national health system. With almost three out of every four adults affected by overweight or obesity and more than 18% of the adult population -that is, more than 20 million people- suffering from diabetes, the country faces an unsustainable burden.


The Government is clear about this and the Undersecretary of Health, Eduardo Clark, made it clear at last week's presidential conference: the health sector allocates close to 180 billion pesos annually to attend to the complications derived from overweight, obesity, diabetes and hypertension. This figure covers all public systems, from IMSS and ISSSTE to IMSS Bienestar, Pemex, Sedena and Semar. What he failed to say is that this amount is insufficient; what is missing is a strategy with resources to face the deep crisis we are in.
And another thing is that the overflow does not only lie in the prevalence of these diseases, but in their mismanagement and the serious consequences they generate. The 100 thousand people with chronic renal damage who require dialysis or hemodialysis, estimated by Clark, and who require dialysis or hemodialysis, cost an average of 415 thousand pesos per patient per year, but the solution is not treatment but prevention. In addition, 4 out of 10 consultations in IMSS family medicine units are directly related to these conditions. It is positive in this context that the first national care protocols (Pronams) have included these conditions, but as soon as they are implemented and the results are noticed, the overflow of the system is already undeniable.
The government focuses its narrative on the excessive consumption of soft drinks and junk food, pointing to the companies that produce them as the main culprits. In response, it raises excise taxes (IEPS) on these products, with the expectation of collecting an additional 41 billion pesos. Undoubtedly, this measure may discourage consumption and generate revenue for the public treasury, which needs it so much. However, it is absolutely insufficient to face an epidemic of this magnitude. The $40 billion pales in comparison to the $180 billion already spent on treatment, and does not address the deep roots of the problem. It is like trying to put out a forest fire with a glass of water: convenient to collect, but ineffective to solve.
This crisis is not new; it has been thoroughly diagnosed for decades. We all know -and it has been repeated ad nauseam- that overweight and obesity affect one out of every three children and adolescents, and seven out of every ten adults in Mexico. It is our main epidemic, but so far we have not implemented comprehensive strategies to combat it. Since 2012, when Dr. David Kershenobich, current Secretary of Health, presided over the National Academy of Medicine (ANM), together with the then rector of the UNAM, José Narro Robles, and an interdisciplinary group of experts in nutrition, health, agriculture, economics, politics, psychology, anthropology and sociology, among other disciplines, prepared the report "Obesity in Mexico: recommendations for a State policy". This document already emphasized the need for a multifactorial approach.
In 2018, the National Institute of Public Health (INSP), led by Juan Rivera, published the book "Obesity in Mexico. State of public policy and specific recommendations for its prevention and control", with the participation of more than 75 scientists. In its prologue, the book highlights that the high incidence of obesity in Mexico is a reflection of a complex and multifactorial reality, influenced by health and social determinants such as access to healthy foods, cultural patterns, urban environments that discourage physical activity, and psychological and economic factors. The book, structured in ten chapters, details recommendations that go beyond taxes and nutritional front labeling -measures that are included, but not as the only solutions. It would be worthwhile for the head of health today to review these publications, in which he himself participated, and present them to the tax authorities who determine where to allocate the budget.
It will be costly to insist on a reductionist vision.
Among the key proposals are the regulation of food and beverage advertising aimed at children, preventive interventions in the school context, communication campaigns to encourage behavioral changes and healthy lifestyles, and policies to promote physical activity in community and work environments. It also addresses issues such as the reformulation of industrial products to reduce sugars and fats, the strengthening of sustainable agriculture to improve access to fresh food, and the involvement of civil society in educational programs. It is not all about taxing soft drinks; a holistic approach that integrates health, education, economics and urban planning is needed.
If the government persists in a reductionist vision, focused only on the consumption of sugary and processed beverages, as is the discourse of President Claudia Sheinbaum, we will continue to pay an exorbitant price in lives, resources and productivity. The unsustainable burden of obesity and diabetes demands urgent and comprehensive action, based on scientific evidence and cross-sector collaboration. It is time to move from diagnosis to comprehensive action: for the sake of millions of Mexicans and the viability of our health system.
Mexico faces cardio renal metabolic syndrome
And without getting off the subject, therapeutic options are now emerging that make it possible to simultaneously address diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease and heart problems, known as cardio renal metabolic syndrome (CRMS). The pharmaceutical company Boehringer Ingelheim is launching empagliflozin, a molecule that seeks to treat CRM together, seeking to break the cycle that unites them and offer those living with it a better life and fewer complications. Specialists mention that recognizing that the 3 diseases are united in a delicate balance where damage to one can trigger malfunction in the others, is a medical advance and an urgent call to see the patient as a whole, treating what is hidden behind scattered and silent symptoms.
October 8 and 9 comes ExpoFac de RX Mexico
ExpoFac, organized by the transnational RX in Mexico for the pharmaceutical and personal care retail industry, is in its third edition and will take place at Expo Guadalajara on October 8 and 9, where some 3,000 visitors are expected. The pharmaceutical retail segment is equivalent to some 663 million pesos operated, according to INEGI, by some 65,000 business units that sell some type of medicine or pharmaceutical products, although not all of them are formally pharmacies. We are told that 60-70% of the attendees come from Guadalajara, Michoacán, León and Colima, but also from places like Yucatán, Monterrey, Sinaloa, Sonora, Tijuana and Tamaulipas. There are 30 scholarships available for a certification offered in collaboration with Anafarmex. The topic of pharmacies adjacent to pharmacies will not be missing from the event's program.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BPK3-RS0R-C544-00000-00Pediatricians warn of impact of wildfire smoke on children's health even at great distance2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisPediatricians warn of impact of wildfire smoke on children's health even at great distance


The Spanish Association of Pediatrics (AEP) has warned this Tuesday that the impact of smoke from forest fires currently affecting Spain has health risks for children and adolescents, even hundreds of kilometers away, due to the fact that atmospheric currents can transport the polluting particles present in the smoke to towns that do not have a fire in their vicinity.


The agency's Environmental Health Committee (CSM-AEP) has prepared a report detailing that this smoke contains fine and ultrafine suspended particles (PM2.5), carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NOx), hydrocyanic acid (HCN) and other potentially carcinogenic organic compounds, whose exposure can have immediate and long-term effects.
In the short term, their inhalation can cause an aggravation of chronic respiratory diseases (asthma, allergic rhinitis), an increase in acute respiratory infections, eye and mucosal irritation (conjunctivitis, coughing, throat clearing) and carbon monoxide or cyanide poisoning; while in the long term, repeated exposure can contribute to the development of respiratory, cardiovascular or immunological diseases, in addition to possible neurotoxic effects that alter neurological development.
Exposure to this type of smoke can also affect children's mental health and psychological well-being, and can lead to anxiety and stress, both in the short and long term.
Pediatricians have also shown their concern about the fact that the number of forest fires and the area burned in Spain has increased "significantly" in recent years, according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), a trend that is linked to climate change and is expected to continue to intensify.
"Added to these environmental risks is the particular vulnerability of children and adolescents, both because of their developing physiology and behavioral exposure: they breathe more air per kilogram of weight than adults, tend to spend more time outdoors, and depend on adults to keep them safe," the pediatricians added.
MEASURES AGAINST THE IMPACT OF SMOKE FROM FIRES
For all these reasons, the CSM-AEP has published a document in which it has included a series of measures for prevention and reduction of the risks associated with this type of smoke, and in which it has included the importance of consulting official alerts, following the warnings of Civil Protection and security forces and contacting 112 in the event of signs of fire or the presence of smoke.
Similarly, it has recommended monitoring air quality through the Air Quality Index viewer of the Ministry for Ecological Transition (MITECO) or its mobile application.
The organization has also advised improving the indoor air in each home, for which windows and doors should be kept closed, using purifiers with appropriate filters (ISO16890 ePM1 or higher) and putting the air conditioner in recirculation mode.
To avoid additional sources of contamination at home, it is necessary to avoid smoking or using combustion systems (wood, gas, candles, barbecues) during episodes of high contamination.
The use of FFP2 masks can also help reduce exposure to particulate matter, and their use is recommended for children from the age of two, provided they can tolerate them adequately.
To cope with fires, pediatricians have stressed the importance of being prepared for emergencies and of having basic supplies (such as water or non-perishable food) and rescue medication in case of chronic pathologies such as asthma. In the event that the authorities recommend evacuation or in the case of not being able to guarantee a safe environment at home, evacuation should be carried out to authorized places, with air conditioning and filtered air.
They have also reported that dizziness, drowsiness, difficulty breathing or behavioral changes may be signs of possible poisoning by carbon monoxide and / or hydrogen cyanide, cases in which should go "immediately" to an emergency room. In case of doubt, the health center or the Pediatric Environmental Health Unit (PEHSU) of reference can be consulted.
Before returning to an affected area, it is important to check both the safety of the home, access to basic services such as water or electricity, and to clean up "properly" before exposing children to the environment.
Finally, pediatricians have insisted on the importance of taking care of mental health, since fires can have lasting psychological effects on children, which is why they have recommended observing emotional or behavioral changes and, if necessary, seeking professional support.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BNV3-RS0P-X46X-00000-00León, Zamora and Galicia continue to suffer the effects of the wave of fires2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisLeón, Zamora and Galicia continue to suffer the effects of the wave of fires


The neighbors of La Baña were working yesterday afternoon to eliminate the undergrowth and refresh the terrain, threatened by the flames that were approaching a pine forest through which they could advance with great speed. To this municipality of León came from the bordering Zamora the Porto fire, the one that affected the Alta Sanabria. The northeast of Castilla y León, as well as some parts of the provinces of Ourense and Lugo, suffered yesterday the aftermath of the wave of fires, already much less virulent than last week, but still alive, between out-of-control outbreaks, reactivations of others and some new ones. In Sanabria five villages were evacuated yesterday, four of them for the second time this month, according to EFE. Also in León and Lugo there continue to be evacuated populations.


At the same time there have been significant advances in the fight against the flames, among which stands out the stabilization of the second largest of the fires that have ravaged Galicia during this August, the municipalities of Chandrexa de Queixa and Vilariño de Conso. This is the merger of different outbreaks that, during the 17 days it lasted, burned 19,000 hectares, making it the second largest of which there is statistical record in Galicia, only surpassed by Larouco, in Valdeorras, about 30,000 hectares, dominated last Saturday. The one in Chandrexa and Vilariño has affected an area of great natural value, in the central massif of Ourense.
Castilla y León bears the brunt of the crisis, although the greatest devastation is concentrated in Ourense.
Thus, by midday yesterday there was no longer any fire out of control in Galicia of at least 10,000 ha of burned area, according to official data from the Ministry of Rural Environment. There were four that exceeded that threshold, the two mentioned above, and those of Oímbra and Xinzo, of 17,000, and that of A Mezquita, of 10,000. Now they have yet to be controlled and extinguished.
"This simultaneity of several fires of more than 10,000 hectares has never happened before in Spain", said yesterday to TVE Víctor Fernández, head of the extinction service of the Fasgar fire in León, where similar situations to those in Ourense have been experienced, with contagions between provinces. The forestry engineers emphasize that the proliferation of crises in several communities, such as the Galician and Castilian-Leonese in addition to the Extremadura and Asturias, caused this month a collapse in the system to combat the flames, not being able to provide assistance to each other and require the maximum possible assistance from the central government, through the air and the Military Emergency Unit, UME.
"This simultaneity of several fires of more than 10,000 hectares had never happened before in Spain".
In Galicia persists anyway a forest fire of considerable size, in one of its ecological jewels, the vicinity of Pena Trevinca, in the municipality of Carballeda de Valdeorras, with about 5,000 hectares razed. The neighbors of Casaio have been watching since the weekend that the flames do not cross the river and reach them. There were two other outbreaks, of much smaller size, in Avión, Ourense, and A Pobra de Brollón, Lugo, although in this one the situation of risk was decreed due to the proximity to the houses.
In the province of León, in the afternoon, there were four outbreaks catalogued as level 2, of maximum danger, among which is that of Fasgar, which started sixteen days ago, and which has not been controlled, with frequent reactivations.
The estimated satellite figures, which offer a first approximation in the absence of official data in most of Spain, indicate that more than 400,000 hectares have burned, with the worst record so far this century. Castilla y León is the most affected community, followed by Galicia, in which the province of Ourense suffers the greatest degree of devastation, with 11% of its territory burned. Rains are not expected until tomorrow afternoon or Thursday.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BNV3-RS5Y-618H-00000-00Pediatricians warn of impact of wildfire smoke on children's health even at great distance2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisPediatricians warn of impact of wildfire smoke on children's health even at great distance


The Spanish Association of Pediatrics (AEP) has warned this Tuesday that the impact of smoke from forest fires currently affecting Spain has health risks for children and adolescents, even hundreds of kilometers away, due to the fact that atmospheric currents can transport the polluting particles present in the smoke to towns that do not have a fire in their vicinity.


The agency's Environmental Health Committee (CSM-AEP) has prepared a report detailing that this smoke contains fine and ultrafine suspended particles (PM2.5), carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NOx), hydrocyanic acid (HCN) and other potentially carcinogenic organic compounds, whose exposure can have immediate and long-term effects.
In the short term, their inhalation can cause an aggravation of chronic respiratory diseases (asthma, allergic rhinitis), an increase in acute respiratory infections, eye and mucosal irritation (conjunctivitis, coughing, throat clearing) and carbon monoxide or cyanide poisoning; while in the long term, repeated exposure can contribute to the development of respiratory, cardiovascular or immunological diseases, in addition to possible neurotoxic effects that alter neurological development.
Exposure to this type of smoke can also affect children's mental health and psychological well-being, and can lead to anxiety and stress, both in the short and long term.
Pediatricians have also shown their concern about the fact that the number of forest fires and the area burned in Spain has increased "significantly" in recent years, according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), a trend that is linked to climate change and is expected to continue to intensify.
"Added to these environmental risks is the particular vulnerability of children and adolescents, both because of their developing physiology and behavioral exposure: they breathe more air per kilogram of weight than adults, tend to spend more time outdoors, and depend on adults to keep them safe," the pediatricians added.
MEASURES AGAINST THE IMPACT OF SMOKE FROM FIRES

For all these reasons, the CSM-AEP has published a document in which it has included a series of measures for prevention and reduction of the risks associated with this type of smoke, and in which it has included the importance of consulting official alerts, following the warnings of Civil Protection and security forces and contacting 112 in the event of signs of fire or the presence of smoke.
Similarly, it has recommended monitoring air quality through the Air Quality Index viewer of the Ministry for Ecological Transition (MITECO) or its mobile application.
The organization has also advised improving the indoor air in each home, for which windows and doors should be kept closed, using purifiers with appropriate filters (ISO16890 ePM1 or higher) and putting the air conditioner in recirculation mode.
To avoid additional sources of contamination at home, it is necessary to avoid smoking or using combustion systems (wood, gas, candles, barbecues) during episodes of high contamination.
The use of FFP2 masks can also help reduce exposure to particulate matter, and their use is recommended for children from the age of two, provided they can tolerate them adequately.
To cope with fires, pediatricians have stressed the importance of being prepared for emergencies and of having basic supplies (such as water or non-perishable food) and rescue medication in case of chronic pathologies such as asthma. In the event that the authorities recommend evacuation or in the case of not being able to guarantee a safe environment at home, evacuation should be carried out to authorized places, with air conditioning and filtered air.
They have also reported that dizziness, drowsiness, difficulty breathing or behavioral changes may be signs of possible poisoning by carbon monoxide and / or hydrogen cyanide, cases in which should go "immediately" to an emergency room. In case of doubt, the health center or the Pediatric Environmental Health Unit (PEHSU) of reference can be consulted.
Before returning to an affected area, it is important to check both the safety of the home, access to basic services such as water or electricity, and to clean up "properly" before exposing children to the environment.
Finally, pediatricians have insisted on the importance of taking care of mental health, since fires can have long-lasting psychological effects on children, which is why they have recommended observing emotional or behavioral changes and, if necessary, seeking professional support.

urn:contentItem:6GMG-RFH3-S6GH-N130-00000-00Fires break records in Europe, with the Iberian Peninsula as its main victim2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisFires break records in Europe, with the Iberian Peninsula as its main victim


So far this year, the area burned in the European Union (EU) has exceeded one million hectares, the worst figure since records have been kept, largely due to the intense fires in August in the Iberian Peninsula that left thousands of people dead, thousands evacuated and protected areas razed to the ground.


With one month left in the fire season, the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) counts 1,016,425 hectares (ha) burned, surpassing the 993,558 ha of 2017, so far the record since records began in 2006.
Spain and Portugal alone concentrate more than 60% of the area razed by fire in the 27 countries. In the Spanish case, fires have devastated 377,234 ha, 37% of the total, while in Portugal the figure amounts to 260,358 ha, 25%.
Related to this topic
Opinion
Not only the people save the people
Pablo Batalla
The month began with an intense heat wave that was felt throughout southern Europe, but especially in the two Iberian countries. In Spain it lasted 16 days and became the most powerful since records have been kept, with an anomaly of 4.6 degrees.
According to a report released Friday by the State Meteorological Agency (Aemet), the spring of this year - "very wet" in much of the peninsula - favored an extraordinary growth of vegetation that, after a dry and warm June and July, became fuel for fires.
The flames not only devastated the territory, but also triggered polluting gases. According to EFFIS, between January 1 and August 26, 38.37 million tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) were released as a result of the fires, more than three times as much as in the same period in 2024 (11.46 million).
Copernicus Atmospheric Monitoring Service (CAMS) scientist Mark Parrington called the emissions from the Spanish and Portuguese fires during August "exceptional," and warned that the large amounts of smoke and PM2.5 particles caused a "serious deterioration of air quality" in the Iberian Peninsula and parts of France.
Related to this topic.Rain and falling temperatures give respite to fires in Spain
EFE
Spain and Portugal, the most affected
In Spain, regions such as Castilla y León (center-north), Galicia (northwest) or Extremadura (west) have been the most affected by forest fires which, in the last weeks, registered more than twenty serious outbreaks active at the same time.
The fires have left at least eight dead so far this year and, in August alone, forced the evacuation of more than 35,000 people, burned villages, protected natural areas or cut roads and railways.
Related to this topicThe situation of fires in Spain evolves favorably, although with several foci still active
Público / EFE

The landscape of Las Médulas (León), where the largest open-pit gold mine of the Roman Empire is located, listed by Unesco as a World Heritage Site, has been engulfed in flames that took with them some of its centenary chestnut trees. Areas of the Picos de Europa National Park were also burned and pilgrims walking the Camino de Santiago on stretches close to the fires were affected.
Portugal, although with fewer total hectares burned, is the EU country with the highest percentage of territory consumed by the flames, 2.83%, concentrated mainly in the central and northern regions.
The wave of fires left four deaths, evacuations and also affected natural areas, with a fire in the Douro International Natural Park, in the north, and a fire in the Arganil area (center) that devastated more than 64,400 hectares, making it one of the largest fires in its history.
The powerful heat wave of this August also favored the advance of fires in countries such as Albania and Greece, where fatalities and evictions were recorded. In Greece, with 46,783 hectares burned, an area well below that of other years in which more than 100,000 hectares were burned, the heat and winds led to the outbreak of 152 fires in 24 hours in the middle of the month.
The situation in the northern Peloponnese, with outbreaks out of control, forced the evacuation of some 7,500 people and, days earlier, a fire in the southeast of Athens left one dead. The European Space Agency (ESA) recalled last Wednesday that the long-term challenge is that these phenomena are expected to become more frequent and intense as the climate crisis worsens.

Cheryl Rofer

August 30th, 2025 ( Lawyers, Guns, and Money - Delivered by Newstex )

Jose is at the window, Luca is on the landing,

and Zooey is wondering why he has to put up with this.

Last night, social media lit up with speculation about whether Donald Trump had died. He hadn't been seen in public, and there were a variety of auguries that could be made to point to his death. Much giddiness, although the people I follow on Bluesky seemed aware that it was all speculation. The conversation there was also very indirect. There's been a lot of indirect references for the past week or so. Discussion on X seems to have been more direct. A trending topic was 'Is Trump dead?' This morning a photo emerged of Trump emerging to play golf, so we're back to the sameold sameold.

A midweek pick-me-up of three televised hours of Cabinet members doing their imitation of North Korean governmental figures was one of the auguries. It was generally agreed that special envoy Steve Witkoff outdid the group with his insistence that the 'Noble' prize committee recognize Trump.

More uproar and pushback this week.

Governor J.B. Pritzker told Trump not to send the National Guard to Chicago, and other Illinois politicians and others - I think I saw the Chicago chief of police - have echoed the message. Pritzker says that nobody from the administration has talked to him or anyone in Illinois about it. The administration counters with leaks of alleged plans.

Trump tried to fire Fed governor Lisa Cook, on a pretext cooked up by real estate heir and Federal Housing Finance Agency director Bill Pulte, who is using his access to records to find what he calls mortgage fraud in the records for people Trump doesn't like. Maybe Pulte Homes is susceptible to the same sort of pressures that have hurt Tesla.

Cook is fighting the firing in court. A hearing was held Friday.

Also fired was the head of the CDC, Susan Monarez. Three other CDC executives quit in sympathy, and the staff turned out to honor them publicly. The cause is said to have been a disagreement with RFK Jr. on vaccine policcy, but I haven't seen a full discussion of that situation, which seems to have spanned most of the week and perhaps more before that.

RFK Jr. has nominated his deputy, Jim O'Neill, whose expertise lies in puffing up Peter Thiel's seasteading fantasy, to replace Monarez.

Folk associated with the CDC are demanding that RFK Jr. be fired. A number of members of Congress, including Bernie Sanders and Chuck Schumer, are supporting that demand.

The National Guard presence in DC was upgraded by having some of them carry guns, but they are also picking up litter and spreading mulch in place of the fired National Park Service employees.

ICE took two people away from fighting a forest fire in Washington State and raided a high school football game.

On the other hand, the Florida concentration camp was shut down, and it seems like the court order is being obeyed.

So.1)The state of Florida spent >$200 million to build the facility it calls "Alligator Alcatraz"2) It opened in early July, christened by Trump.3) Now it is closing, due to a judge's order.4) It will cost $20 million to dismantle the center, which was used for about 2 months.

- Bill Grueskin (@bgrueskin.bsky.social) 2025-08-28T19:23:41.837Z

Europe continues to negotiate with Iran, because Trump's bombings didn't end that situation. Europe wants an agreement with Iran in 30 days or they will invoke the 'snapback' provision of the JCPOA to put sanctions back in place.

James Fallows has a particularly good summary of the bad and good this week.

Follow the court-watchers for the details of the lawsuits. Chris Geidner(LawDork, Bluesky), Roger Parloff(Lawfare, Bluesky), and the Just Security tracker.

As usual, keep it to things that have actually happened, not hypotheticals. What is actually happening is bad enough.

Caring for yourself and loved ones is resistance too. Post your pets. I am working on finding a piano teacher and have ordered three Kitty Holsters and leashes because Zooey is becoming more interested in going outside.

176 more weeks to go. What are you doing?

Previous weeks: Week 10, Week 20, Week 30, Week 31

The post Week 32 appeared first on Lawyers, Guns & Money.

Link to the original story.

urn:contentItem:6GR9-G0S3-RS90-52VN-00000-00gongloff-trillions-in-wages-going-up-in-wildfire-smoke2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSgongloff-trillions-in-wages-going-up-in-wildfire-smokeMark GongloffThe Press Democrat, Santa Rosa, Calif.

The climate emergency has produced several on-the-nose metaphorical moments lately, such as an art museum founded by oil baron J. Paul Getty being threatened by the Palisades fire in Los Angeles in January or a superyacht’s fireworks sparking a wildfire in Greece last year. But nothing tops how more than $1 trillion in U.S. wages has gone up in literal smoke from fires hundreds of miles away, according to a new study. It’s a reminder that climate change is no longer a problem for our grandchildren but is inflicting profound economic and health damage right now. It’s also a reminder there are few if any places to hide from the consequences of our failure to address this crisis.

From 2020 through 2024, U.S. workers in the retail, wholesale, transportation, construction, mining and agriculture industries alone lost $1.1 trillion in wages because of exposure to wildfire smoke, according to a new estimate by Bloomberg Intelligence. Analyst Andrew John Stevenson focused on these industries because they’re the most exposed to smoke, which causes people to miss work and generally be less productive. (It’s not easy to drive a truck or a bulldozer when you can’t breathe.) Wages in these industries represent just $2.8 trillion out of $11.4 trillion in total U.S. wages. In other words, to the extent other industries suffered from smoke, that $1.1 trillion in losses will be higher — possibly much higher. The Bloomberg estimate is based on a 2022 National Bureau of Economic Research paper suggesting one day of exposure to wildfire smoke reduces a person’s quarterly wages by roughly 0.1%. Expose enough people to smoke for long enough, and pretty soon you’re talking real money. In 2023, for example, Americans suffered through 150 smoke days, thanks to a record wildfire season in Canada. That cut the wages of Bloomberg Intelligence’s chosen industries by $407 billion that year alone. That group’s wage losses over the past five years are almost six times as high as between 2006 and 2010. Typically, the fire-prone West Coast has been the most vulnerable to wage impacts from smoke. But the recent surge in Canadian wildfires has shifted that burden to the U.S. Midwest, where workers in vulnerable industries are especially concentrated. In some counties in Minnesota and the Dakotas, more than a quarter of all wages in these industries were lost in Canada’s record fire season of 2023. Smoke from the 2023 fires caused the worst air pollution in the U.S. since 2011, according to a recent University of Chicago study. Counties in Alaska, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan and Texas replaced California counties in the ranks of the most-polluted places in the U.S. that year. This year is turning out to be another bad one for Canada, with 8.3 million hectares (or 21 million acres) burned so far, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, on pace to be at least the second-worst season ever. Smoke from these fires has taken air quality across the U.S. to levels not seen since those dark (orange) days of 2023. Wildfire smoke is a nightmare for human health, 10 times more toxic than regular pollution, according to Stanford University researchers. Its particulate matter attacks not only lungs but all other organs, contributing to heart disease, cancer, dementia, low birth weights and more. It causes emergency-room visits to surge, especially by uninsured people. Those costs are a blow to municipal health care borrowers, a recent Dallas Federal Reserve study noted. Hospitals and nursing homes in high-smoke areas paid an extra $250 million in interest due to wildfire smoke alone between 2010 and 2019, according to the study. That could more than double to $570 million in the next decade. As with wage impacts, the hit to borrowers has shifted from the West Coast in recent years. In 2023, for example, some health care borrowers on the East Coast faced five times more smoke exposure than they did between 2010 and 2019. Wildfires have broken out for as long as there have been trees and lightning, of course. And humans are responsible for setting most fires. But a hotter planet makes those fires more likely and intense by making air hotter and foliage drier. In parts of the U.S., wildfire season is now two months longer than it was in 1973, according to the research group Climate Central. The U.S. acreage burned each year has doubled in the past 20 years from its average between 1983 and 2004, according to the National Interagency Fire Center. Meanwhile, the amount of toxic wildfire smoke that Americans in the Lower 48 states have been exposed to has also doubled in the past five years from the levels in 2006-19, according to researchers at Stanford and the University of Washington. Smoke deaths alone could inflict $244 billion in annual U.S. economic damage by 2050, according to a National Bureau of Economic Research paper last year. Wildfire smoke can’t be avoided or contained, though better forest management and wildfire response can help limit it. Burning fewer fossil fuels, thus slowing the pace at which we’re heating the planet, will also help. Instead, President Donald Trump’s administration relentlessly attacks the clean energy industry, environmental standards and anything else related to climate change while slashing funding for federal disaster response and health research. All of this is being done in the name of favoring economic growth over “wokeness.” But until we treat wildfire smoke and climate change like the metastasizing national health emergencies they are, both our physical health and economic growth will continue to be stunted. Mark Gongloff is a columnist for Bloomberg Opinion. You can send letters to the editor to letters@pressdemocrat.com

urn:contentItem:6GJ5-YXS3-RSB2-C4FC-00000-00Spain's blazing summer2025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. A019Spain's blazing summer

Record temperatures and drought intensify infernos as firefighters and locals battle without enough resources

Thousands of firefighters backed by soldiers and water-bombing aircraft battled over 20 major wildfires raging across western Spain, where officials say a record area of land has already been burnt.

Spain and neighbouring Portugal have been particularly affected by forest fires fuelled by heatwaves and drought blamed on climate change that have hit southern Europe.

Two firefighters were killed on Monday - one in each country, both in road accidents - taking the death toll to two in Portugal and four in Spain.

Spain's civil protection chief Virginia Barcones told public television TVE that 23 blazes were classified as "operational level two", meaning they pose a direct threat to nearby communities.

The fires, now in their second week, are concentrated in the western regions of Castile and Leon, Galicia and Extremadura, where thousands of people have been forced to flee their homes.

Residents said they were frustrated with what they regarded as poor preparation and limited resources.

"No one's shown up here, nobody," Patricia Vila, 42, told AFPTV in the village of Vilamartin de Valdeorras in Ourense province of Galicia.

"Not a single damn helicopter, not one plane, has come to drop water and cool things down a bit."

Signs of the fires were everywhere in the province, from ashen forests and blackened soil to destroyed homes, with thick smoke forcing people to wear masks.

Firefighters battled the flames as locals in just shorts and T-shirts used water from hoses and buckets to try to stop the spread.

More than 343,000ha of land - the equivalent of nearly half a million football pitches - have been destroyed this year in Spain, setting a new national record, according to the European Forest Fire Information System. The previous record of 306,000ha was set in the same period three years ago.

Spain is being helped with firefighting aircraft from France, Italy, Slovakia and the Netherlands, while Portugal is receiving air support from Sweden and Morocco.

But the size and severity of the fires and the intensity of the smoke - visible from space - were making "airborne action" difficult," Spanish Defence Minister Margarita Robles told TVE.

"It's a very difficult, very complicated situation," she added.

Thousands of people have been forced to flee their homes since the wildfires began last week.

"We had to run away because the fire was coming in from everywhere - everywhere, above us, below us, all around," said Isidoro, 83, in Vilamartin de Valdeorras.

Across the border in Portugal, some 2000 firefighters were deployed across the north and centre of the country on Tuesday, with about half of them concentrated in the town of Arganil.

Some 216,000ha of land have been destroyed across Portugal since the start of the year.

Portuguese Prime Minister Luis Montenegro said the country had endured 24 days of weather conditions of "unprecedented severity" with high temperature and strong winds. "We are at war, and we must triumph in this fight," he added.

Officials in both countries expressed hope that the weather would turn to help tackle the fires.

Spain's meteorological agency said the heatwave, which has seen temperatures hit 45C in parts of the country, was coming to an end.

Officials in Castile and Leon said a firefighter died on Monday when the water truck he was driving flipped over on a steep forest road and down a slope, days after two other volunteer firefighters were killed in the region.

A Romanian employee of a riding school north of Madrid lost his life trying to protect horses from the fire.

In Portugal, President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa said a firefighter died on Monday in a traffic accident that left two colleagues seriously injured.

A former mayor in the eastern town of Guarda died on Saturday while trying to tackle a fire.

- AFP

urn:contentItem:6FCS-SS93-RS39-C0B7-00000-00New Machine Learning Study Findings Reported from Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Kharagpur (A Synergistic Approach Using Machine Learning and Deep Learning for Forest Fire Susceptibility In Himalayan Forests)2025-03-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisMACHINE LEARNINGNew Machine Learning Study Findings Reported from Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Kharagpur (A Synergistic Approach Using Machine Learning and Deep Learning for Forest Fire Susceptibility In Himalayan Forests)


2025 MAR 21 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Robotics & Machine Learning Daily News Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on Machine Learning. According to news reporting from West Bengal, India, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forests, often referred to as the lungs of the Earth, are increasingly suffering from multiple fire events in a warming world, heightening the risk of species loss and ecosystem disturbance. Forest fires significantly challenge the diverse life forms and ecosystem services these environments provide."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Kharagpur, "This study evaluates and predicts forest fire susceptibility in the Sikkim Himalayan forests using machine learning and deep learning (Rprop + algorithm) frameworks, including a bagging-based ensemble Random Forest (RF) and a boosting-based ensemble Gradient Boosting Model, integrating the environmental variables of the forest landscape to predict fire susceptibility. Notably, the RF model outperformed the deep learning model, which required extensive datasets or variables to discern the underlying patterns. Out of the three models, RF has shown an overall accuracy of 89.43%, precision of 88.56%, recall of 90.23%, F1 Score of 89.40%, AUC of 0.894, and kappa of 0.788. Factors such as proximity to roads and wind velocity, along with anthropogenic activities such as biomass burning, land clearing, and slash-and-burn agriculture by villagers, significantly influence forest fires. Identifying high-risk zones, particularly in the western and southern districts, has critical implications for forest fire management in Sikkim. The findings of this study offer valuable insights for decision-makers, aiding in the development of appropriate mitigation measures and policies."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This research underscores the importance of preserving these crucial ecosystems and establishes a foundation for proactive fire prevention strategies and sustainable ecosystem management practices."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: A Synergistic Approach Using Machine Learning and Deep Learning for Forest Fire Susceptibility In Himalayan Forests. Journal of the Indian Society of Remote Sensing, 2025. Journal of the Indian Society of Remote Sensing can be contacted at: Springer, One New York Plaza, Suite 4600, New York, Ny, United States. (Springer - www.springer.com; Journal of the Indian Society of Remote Sensing - www.springerlink.com/content/0255-660x/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Mukunda Dev Behera, Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Kharagpur, Ctr Ocean River Atmosphere & Land Sci, Kharagpur 721302, West Bengal, India. Additional authors for this research include Parthiva Shome, A. Jaya Prakash, Sujoy Mudi, P. V. Vinod, Pulakesh Das, Satyajit Behera, Basanta Kumar Prusty, Bikash Ranjan Parida, Biswajeet Pradhan, Sanjeev Kumar Srivastava and Parth Sarathi Roy.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1007/s12524-025-02157-4. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
