urn:contentItem:6GNC-37S3-RRWN-N18R-00000-00Fitch Rates CMPC's Hybrid Notes 'BB+'2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisFitch Rates CMPC's Hybrid Notes 'BB+'

Key Highlights:

* Fitch Ratings assigned a 'BB+' rating to the 35-year subordinated bond issued by InversionesCMPC S.A., guaranteed by Empresas CMPC S.A.

* The bonds are eligible for 50% equity credit and will be used for general corporate purposes, including debt repayment and investments in Eligible Green Projects and/or Eligible Social Projects.

* The proposed issuance is rated two notches below CMPC's Long-Term Issuer Default Rating (IDR) to reflect higher loss severity and increased default risk compared to senior obligations.

Original Press Release:

Rio de Janeiro, Sept. 2 -- Fitch Ratings issued the following news release:

Fitch Ratings assigned a 'BB+' rating to the 35-year subordinated bond to be issued by InversionesCMPC S.A. (rated BBB; Negative Outlook), guaranteed by Empresas CMPC S.A. (BBB; Negative Outlook). The bonds are eligible for 50% equity credit. Proceeds from the issuance will be used for general corporate purposes, including debt repayment.

The proposed bonds meet Fitch's criteria for subordination, cross-defaults, absence of relevant restrictive covenants, effective maturity of at least five years, ability to defer coupons for at least five years, and absence of look-back clauses. As a result, the securities are eligible for 50% equity credit.

The proposed issuance is rated two notches below CMPC's Long-Term Issuer Default Rating (IDR) to reflect higher loss severity and increased default risk compared to senior obligations. This approach is aligned with Fitch's "Corporate Hybrids Treatment and Notching Criteria," published on April 8, 2025.

KEY RATING DRIVERS

Equity Treatment: Fitch expects the hybrid bond will be subordinated, with priority only over CMPC's equity capital. The issuer may defer coupon payments at its discretion, with deferred coupon payments being cumulative. The bonds have a formal maturity date in 2057, and CMPC has a call option to redeem them after seven years from the issue date. Call dates are not considered effective maturity dates under Fitch's criteria, until interest rate step-ups reach 100 basis points.

Use of Proceeds: Fitch expects the funds from the issuance to be used for debt repayment and strengthening liquidity, as well as investments in one or more Eligible Green Projects and/or Eligible Social Projects, and other general corporate purposes. Fitch projects that this transaction will strengthen CMPC's capital structure, but its ratios will remain outside the downgrade sensitivity thresholds based on FY 2025 figures.

For more information, please see "Fitch Affirms CMPC's IDRs at 'BBB'; Outlook Revised to Negative," published July 23, 2025 at www.fitchratings.com.

RATING SENSITIVITIES

Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Negative Rating Action/Downgrade

* Average net debt/EBITDA above 3.0x throughout the pulp price cycle;

* Deterioration in macroeconomic conditions that weakens demand for the tissue businesses and prices.

Factors that Could, Individually or Collectively, Lead to Positive Rating Action/Upgrade

* Average net debt/EBITDA below 2.0x throughout the pulp price cycle.

REFERENCES FOR SUBSTANTIALLY MATERIAL SOURCE CITED AS KEY DRIVER OF RATING

The principal sources of information used in the analysis are described in the Applicable Criteria.

MACROECONOMIC ASSUMPTIONS AND SECTOR FORECASTS

Click here to access Fitch's latest quarterly Global Corporates Macro and Sector Forecasts data file which aggregates key data points used in our credit analysis. Fitch's macroeconomic forecasts, commodity price assumptions, default rate forecasts, sector key performance indicators and sector-level forecasts are among the data items included.

ESG CONSIDERATIONS

CMPC and InversionesCMPC have an ESG Relevance Score of '4' for Exposure to Environmental Impacts as Chilean forestry companies are exposed to forest fire risk, which has a negative impact on the credit profile and is relevant to the ratings in conjunction with other factors.

CMPC and InversionesCMPC have an ESG Relevance Score of '4' [+] for Environment - Energy Management as the company sells excess energy to the grid from cogeneration based upon a renewable resource, which has a positive impact on the credit profile and is relevant to the ratings in conjunction with other factors.

The highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of '3', unless otherwise disclosed in this section. A score of '3' means ESG issues are credit-neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity. Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores are not inputs in the rating process; they are an observation on the relevance and materiality of ESG factors in the rating decision. For more information on Fitch's ESG Relevance Scores, visit https://www.fitchratings.com/topics/esg/products#esg-relevance-scores.

RATING ACTIONS

urn:contentItem:6GRD-DTV3-RRJM-X1CR-00000-00Postecoglou promises rapid change after getting a brutal welcome back2025-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisSPORT;NEWSPg. 5Postecoglou promises rapid change after getting a brutal welcome backManager given idea of his task as Forest are exposed by Arsenal thanks to Zubimendi's doublePaul Hayward

The revolution starts on Wednesday. In Swansea. In the Carabao Cup. Nottingham Forest's new manager Ange Postecoglou watched a predictable 3-0 defeat at Arsenal sail by and then promised immediate change in South Wales in midweek.

After a lugubrious start to his post-match briefing, Postecoglou remembered he needed to boost morale and switched tones when he was asked how long it would take to remake Forest in his image. Weeks or months? "No, mate, it won't be months, it won't be weeks - it'll be Wednesday. I can't afford to waste time," he said. "This is not a project. This club had a strong season last year and needs to be stronger this year.

"My job is to get us to where I want us as quickly as possible. On Wednesday we'll start seeing some real principles embedded. It won't take long. I'm not going to let it take long to make sure we turn around."

Swansea City have been warned. And Postecoglou has heaped pressure on himself by promising such a quick reinvention, a change of style some Forest fans may feel isn't necessary, given how well Nuno Espírito Santo did before falling out with the club's owner. This defeat began with Arsenal using Forest as a practice wall as they endeavour to improve their attacking play. Goals from Martín Zubimendi (two) and Viktor Gyökeres and auspicious performances from Noni Madueke and Eberechi Eze raised Arsenal's sights while setting out the cost of what Postecoglou called "a very disruptive week for [my] players".

An ex-Spurs manager was never going to elicit much sympathy here, so when Arsenal's third goal went in, the home crowd sang: "Are you Tottenham in disguise?" In his all-blue casual weekend wear, Postecoglou stood in his classic fact-finding stance: hands in pockets, eyes roaming to assess the task he took on 95 days after being sacked four and a half miles up the road.

For the second consecutive match Forest lost 3-0 to a London club, first with Nuno, then with Postecoglou. The buccaneering spirit of last season has yet to re-emerge. It's way too soon to call it a full Forest fire but Postecoglou has inherited a mood of uncertainty and instability at one of the league's fastest-rising clubs.

They returned from international week with one full training session to assess where Douglas Luiz, Dilane Bakwa, Arnaud Kalimuendo, Omari Hutchinson, James McAtee and Jair Cunha might fit in. Postecoglou took charge on Tuesday. Nobody rewrites a playing style in four days.

The only change he made to the side that lost 3-0 to West Ham was forced: Ola Aina's hamstring injury opening the gate for Morato, who was hounded by Madueke on Arsenal's right. Watching all this, Postecoglou said he would now start "pinning down some of the principles of how we want to play".

Appointed 13 hours after Nuno's exit, and with £180m of summer signings to sort through, he arrived with analysts obsessing over a likely tactical reinvention - from low line to high line, from "backing off to pressing hard", as one put it; from going direct to passing through the lines.

Usually this indicates a confused identity. Successful clubs don't generally change their core ideas with each new manager. It throws players off track. Sometimes, though, the cost of having a headstrong owner is that a manager who is performing well (in this case Nuno) leaves for reasons that have little to do with results.

Evangelos Marinakis, Forest's undeniably headstrong owner, might call Postecoglou an upgrade, because three months ago he was hugging the Europa League trophy. His only victory since has been of the moral kind: the easing out at Spurs of the man who sacked him, Daniel Levy.

With Spurs last season Postecoglou finished 27 points behind Forest. He was one place off relegation in 17th, after 22 defeats in 38 games and 65 goals conceded. Tottenham's 1-0 victory over Manchester United in the Europa League final preserved Postecoglou's impressive trophy-winning record without dispelling the sense that his position there had become untenable.

The Europa League win, which Spurs prioritised as their league campaign succumbed to farce, came 30 years after his coaching career began at South Melbourne. That measure of his coaching ability is the one Forest fans will cling to. And at least he has Elliot Anderson, 22, a roaming, intelligent midfielder with constructive instincts. "We didn't have a lot of the ball today, but every time he was on it, I thought he was unbelievable," said Postecoglou. "I'm really excited to work with him. He's still a young man. I've only had 48 hours with him but already I can see he's very ambitious, wants to win, and be the best."

A coach brought in to "win trophies", Postecoglou has a more immediate job than that. Nuno passed a vital dressing room test. He improved the team, gave them shape and a shared identity and purpose. Recently promoted sides crave those certainties. Now Postecoglou is constructing a new path to the orchard.

It may work. Either way it will take time. But uncertainty tends not to help when Arsenal are coming at you.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BNV3-RS0P-X3JB-00000-00Active fire map follows: more than 410,000 hectares burned by 20252025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisActive fire map follows: more than 410,000 hectares burned by 2025


The fire exceeds 410,000 hectares so far this year, according to data from EFFIS (European Forest Fire Information System) on Monday. More than 350,000 of these have burned since day 8, when the worst fires began. The new data show just how severe these events are.


Specifically, the devastation reaches 411,315 hectares, among those fires with 30 ha or more (below this size, fires that EFFIS does not include in the overall figure, the figure rises to 417,556). It far exceeds every year since 2006, the first year in the series given by EFFIS for the overall total. It contrasts sharply with the previous year's figure of 42,615 hectares, almost ten times the current area burned, despite the fact that the number of fires since 30 ha is not so far from 2024.
Fortunately, the weather is now more favourable than in the previous week. While on August 17, the hottest day of the year, the AEMET risk map was red, a week later the situation has changed with the end of the heat wave. However, the extreme risk has worsened and is again expanding, among others, throughout Galicia and Castilla y León. This unfavorable situation for the most affected regions, as already shown in the map of the 24th, is extended today and in the coming days.

The moving average helps us understand the scale of these fires. The 30-day average of area burned, taking the origin of the fires to add up all the hectares burned on that day, gives the highest value ever recorded for the decade of fire-by-fire records. Despite the large peaks in the worst affected areas, the intensity of the flames on these days can be appreciated in comparison to other periods.
As we have seen before, the total hectares burned this year is much higher than in previous years of the generic EFFIS series. This data provider, through the seasonal trends in its portal, also uses the average but of the same time from 2006 to 2024 to understand these magnitudes. While this range of years averages 79,380 hectares burned in the last week of December for areas of more than 30 ha, 2025 already has five times that area burned.
The voracity of the fires responsible for the peaks is noticeable in the number of hectares burned, but not so much in the number of fires, although they already reach 250 with more than 30 ha. There is no comparison between the aggressiveness of the current fires in Ourense, Zamora or León and the majority of previous fires in recent history.
Estimated maximum number of hectares burned in a fire
According to the EFFIS, the forest fires of A Rúa, Uña de Quintana, Chandrexa and Benuza would exceed in hectares burned the most terrible records of forest fires since 1968, the first year with data according to the General Statistics of Forest Fires (EGIF) of the Ministry for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge. The one in A Rúa would exceed the one in Cortes de Pallás in Valencia in 2012 by about 15,000 hectares; the one in Chandrexa, by about 10,000. The data collection of both systems differs, but the real-time prediction of EFFIS pending consolidated numbers reflects the extent to which the 2025 fires are relevant.
Four of the 15 fires with the largest area burned in EGIF occurred from 2020 onwards. This shows the extent to which the current climate can wreak havoc through flames, something these EFFIS figures now show. 2025 would enter the fatal years for these catastrophes along with 2022 (3 fires) and, above all, 1994 (6).
For a fire to be considered a large fire, it must reach 500 hectares. According to the EFFIS, 2025 already exceeds 50 major fires, to be updated in the coming years in the statistics of the Ministry.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-DG53-RRXD-50FK-00000-00High temperatures rekindle fires in Zamora and León, and force new evacuations2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisHigh temperatures rekindle fires in Zamora and León, and force new evacuations


Up to 14 serious fires remain active in Castilla y León, Galicia and Asturias after a day marked by weather conditions that have rekindled several outbreaks and forced new evacuations in the fires of Porto (Zamora) and Garaño (León).


Although a more favorable evolution of the weather is expected from this Tuesday, the general director of Civil Protection and Emergencies, Virginia Barcones, has warned that the risk remains extreme and that a reduction in the level of danger is not expected until Thursday or Friday, so it has called for maximum caution.
In parallel, the Civil Guard has arrested Monday a 75-year-old man as the alleged perpetrator of the fire declared in the Leonese municipality of Molinaseca (El Bierzo), the last of the serious fires that have arisen in Castilla y León.
Related to this subjectFeijóo's plan against fires includes measures that already exist and proposals "without technical criteria"
In the province of Zamora, and after three weeks of fires, this afternoon has been ordered the eviction of five localities in the region of Sanabria (San Ciprián de Sanabria, Coso, Rábano, Barrio de Rábano and Escuredo), four of which had already been evacuated in previous days because of the fire started on August 14 in Porto. The flames, which have already reached León territory, present difficulties on three fronts.
Also in León, the fire declared on Sunday in Garaño has forced the evacuation of some 90 people from two new towns, Mora de Luna and Vega de Caballeros. In addition, a section of the CL-626 road, between kilometer points 69 and 80, remains closed.
This fire, possibly intentional, had already forced on Sunday the eviction of Viñayo, Piedrasecha, Portilla de Luna and Següera de Luna, with more than 180 people evacuated. This is one of the four burns with danger level two in the province of León and is the one that most concerns the Integrated Operational Coordination Center (Cecopi). In total, Castilla y León maintains a dozen of serious active fires, with reactivations linked to the weather that have marked the day.
The Xunta de Galicia, meanwhile, has decreed this Monday the situation two of emergency in A Pobra do Brollón (Lugo) by a fire declared in the parish of Abrence, due to the proximity of the flames to the nuclei of Golmar, Conceado and San Pedro.
Related to this subjectThe termination of the contract of 38 workers brings to light the precariousness of means in the Catalan natural parks
Aleix Camprubí

In the province of Ourense two fires are still active. One of them, in Avión, started on Sunday. Another remains in Carballeda de Valdeorras, parish of Casaio, where the fire entered from Porto de Sanabria (Zamora) and has already burned 4,400 hectares, including Pena Trevinca, the highest peak in Galicia.
The Chandrexa de Queixa fire, which had devastated 19,000 hectares and has been for a few days the largest in the history of Galicia, is stabilized, as is the Larouco fire, which has burned 30,000 hectares since last Monday.
Related to this subjectThe Government will turn to Congress and the Senate to dismantle the "hoaxes" of the PP on fires
Miguel Muñoz

In Asturias, the three serious fires that remain active in the southwest show a favorable evolution. The one in Degaña, the one that had generated more concern, has been stabilized for 48 hours. In Genestoso, council of Cangas del Narcea, the backfires executed on Sunday have allowed to control it completely. Since the first fire was declared on August 13 and until Saturday 23, the fire has devastated more than 5,500 hectares in Asturias, mostly pastures of public utility forests.
Meanwhile, in Extremadura, the forest fire in Jarilla (Cáceres), declared on August 12, has already been controlled this Monday after 13 days of work. Specifically, it has burned 17,355 hectares and a perimeter of 170 kilometers, making it the largest fire ever recorded in the history of the region.

urn:contentItem:6GBT-7603-RS6C-24V4-00000-00JIM KERSHNER'S THIS DAY IN HISTORY2025-07-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisCPg. 001JIM KERSHNER'S THIS DAY IN HISTORY

FROM 1975: A jury deliberated only four hours before delivering a guilty verdict in the mail-bomb murder trial of Ricky Anthony Young, 23, of Prosser, Washington.

The jurors made no comment after the verdict, but the judge commended both the prosecutors and the defense counsel for their preparation and diligence.

Marjorie Young, the defendant's wife, was not so complimentary. She approached the Franklin County sheriff and said, "I hope you're happy, Boles. You got the wrong man. You've got to live with that for the rest of your life."

This was the second trial on these charges. The first ended in a hung jury, and it was reported that the jury in that trial was deadlocked 11-1 for conviction.

Superior Court Judge James J. Lawless of Pasco died when he opened the mail-bomb package in his chambers.

Young, now 73, remains in prison at the Coyote Ridge Corrections Center in Connell, Washington.

FROM 1925: The eyes of the region's Prohibition officers were fixed on the skies as they tried to spot a major liquor supplier in North Idaho.

They believed an airplane was flying booze into the region from Canada. The unidentified bootleg-aviator was visiting a different town almost every night. Wallace had been a target several times, as well as towns in the Harrison and St. Maries districts.

Authorities had been alerted to the liquor plane two weeks earlier, but their attempts to spot the plane had been hampered by the fact that numerous planes were in the sky on forest fire patrol.

From the fire beat: Two men from Spokane, John Gleason and Ole Jackson, were killed in the Lamb Creek fire, 30 miles north of Priest River, Idaho.

urn:contentItem:6GR1-WSR3-RS52-S1WC-00000-00A tragedy that disrupted lives: Puerto Rican firefighters remember how they lived through 9/112025-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisA tragedy that disrupted lives: Puerto Rican firefighters remember how they lived through 9/11


He was 21 years old, had never set foot in New York, let alone seen the Twin Towers. But his first time there was among ruins, fire, twisting steel and an indelible smell of tragedy.
This is how Lieutenant Joel Figueroa Betancourt, of the Puerto Rico Fire Department, remembers his arrival at ground zero after the attacks of September 11, 2001, when two commercial airliners hit the buildings, resulting in just over 2,900 deaths.


Today, on the verge of three decades of service, Figueroa relives that experience that transformed him personally and professionally.
"I was sleeping when I was told that the United States had been attacked. I turn on the television and see the towers in flames. At that very moment, while I was watching the second plane hit, I was called to mobilize with the group. That's when I understood that everything had changed, not only that week, but for the rest of my life," he said.
The officer left for New York on September 12 with a squadron specialized in rescue operations. He arrived the next day to a nation in a state of 'shock' and a city with ashes still smoldering.
"Just to tell you the level of debris was massive, the steel beams were gigantic, collapsed on top of each other. It wasn't just two buildings, it was several structures all around. There was an unmistakable smell... a smell of burned human beings, something that firefighters know how to recognize," he recalled in an interview with EL VOCERO.
For 12 days, he worked with his team without rest, with days that exceeded 16 hours, sleeping on improvised cots, but with a single mission: to find survivors.
In numbers
2,977
dead
6,000
wounded
Inside the ruins
The now director of the Puerto Rico Fire Department's Disaster and Forest Fire Division was also inside what was left of one of the towers.
"We entered the basement area and walked on huge beams of bent steel. It was awesome to feel like you were standing on tons and tons of metal. At the time, you don't appreciate the magnitude of what happened, because you're focused on working, but then when you see the photos and compare yourself to the structure, you say, 'Wow, we were tiny in the face of that destruction,'" he recounted in a breathless voice.
Although rumors of possible new attacks were circulating at the time, fear did not overpower him.
"I thought I was invincible. I wasn't afraid of another attack, but I was worried about doing the job right. There was a moment when a beam moved and they ordered an evacuation because they feared another collapse. That's when we all ran, but it was more survival instinct than fear," he confessed.
Looking back, he says that September 11 changed history and also the way the world's emergency services deal with a catastrophe.
"What happened forced us to modernize, to be better prepared. Since then I have worked so that the Puerto Rico Fire Department is ready for any event, because if I learned anything it is that we cannot think that we are exempt from tragedies of that magnitude," he said.
Today, 24 years later, Figueroa is close to retiring with almost 30 years of service. However, he does not hesitate to say that what he experienced in New York reaffirmed his vocation.
"Since I was 15 years old I knew I wanted to be a firefighter, and I have never regretted it. What I experienced on September 11 marked me, but it also gave me more desire to serve and leave a legacy for generations to come. That day changed the world...and it changed the way we responders look at emergencies."
What he said
The level of debris was massive, the steel beams were gigantic, collapsed on top of each other. It wasn't just two buildings, it was several structures all around. There was an unmistakable smell... a smell of burning human beings, something that firefighters know how to recognize.
Joel Figueroa Betancourt
A lesson in life
For Néstor O. Alonso Cuevas, then a 22-year-old firefighter, that morning did not begin like any other. He was on vacation when he first became aware of rumors of an attack in New York.
What he could not imagine was that in a few hours he would receive the call that would change his life and his career.
"First prepare our family, because we practically came out of a fire academy, so we were prepared on the rescue side as well. We were being trained. Our family members were worried and wondered how we were going to be mobilized in a certain hour of imminence. I remember that moment very well," he confessed.
Alonso had been trained by New York rescuers in collapsed structure techniques, and it was his colleagues who had prepared him for the most challenging mission of his career.
"It was such a big space...so big. There were so many areas billowing smoke. One of the first missions we were given was to search a multi-story hotel called Millennium. That was one of the first places we searched; (fortunately) we found people alive," said Alonso, who noted the complexity of the terrain and the tension of every move.
The scene, macabre and devastating, contrasted with the adrenaline of youth: "One has the young fever at last. You don't understand much, our parents do. But you see the news, the images, seeing everything that was happening, the number of people dead and injured, it was quite shocking".
Despite the pain and frustration of that week, his memory remains indelible.
"I will always remember September 11 as a very sad and frustrating story. It left us with a lesson in life and preparedness that we still apply in our work today," concluded Alonso, stressing the need for continuous training and interagency coordination to deal with large-scale emergencies.

urn:contentItem:6GNS-2DH3-RRHB-X46S-00000-00Since 2015, Castilla y León has received state aid against fires equal to the sum of Andalucía, Extremadura and Castilla-La Mancha.2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisSince 2015, Castilla y León has received state aid against fires equal to the sum of Andalucía, Extremadura and Castilla-La Mancha.


A study by the Ministry for Ecological Transition (Miteco) accessed by EL PAÍS reveals how the use of state means to extinguish fires in the last decade greatly exceeded in Castilla y León the rest of the autonomous regions with which it shares risks in terms of threatened forest mass. The sum between the state aid provided since 2015 to Andalusia, Extremadura and Castilla-La Mancha, also very extensive and with large forest masses, is practically equal to that of Castilla y León.


After the wave of fires this summer, the third vice-president and Minister of Ecological Transition, Sara Aagesen, appears this Friday in Congress, after an intervention in the Senate at the end of August in which she already pointed in this direction. He spoke there that it is a "structural fact" that with a similar percentage of forest area with respect to the total of all Spain "certain autonomous communities use most of the national device", taking as a reference the indicator of flight hours. "Let's reflect", said Aagesen, "because autonomous communities with considerable forest areas have different results with the support and reinforcement they receive not only from the Ministry of Ecological Transition, but also from the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Defense".
Up to 600 troops of the Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigades (Brif) plus 56 aircraft make up the ministerial reinforcement means to the communities. Nearly half of this device acted last August on the more than 140,000 hectares of forest burned in Castilla y León. The flames hit the provinces of León, Zamora and Palencia and, although in other territories there have also been multiple fronts, this autonomous region has received the main support of the Government with 47.9% of the 1,436 interventions carried out in Spain with these national resources. The second community that received more state support was Galicia, which required 28%, also very affected by the flames. These data on the deployment contrasts with the statements of the president of the community, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco (PP), who argues that they have a "sufficient" operation and that the meteorology overwhelmed it, although the Board had reports warning of a fatal context.
This territory is, in turn, the largest in Spain and concentrates 18% of the national forest area in its 5.1 million hectares of forest, a growing figure due to depopulation and abandonment of the primary sector.
The Junta has 23 aerial means to fight the fire. The 17 autonomous regions add up to 214 aircrafts for 56 of support provided by the Ministry. Castilla y León, therefore, has 10.8% of the total autonomous aerial means despite having 18% of the Spanish forest land.
Records since 2015 reveal that in this period of time, Castilla y León, a territory governed by the PP since 1987, has required 24.2% of the Ministry's brigade reinforcement flight hours: 12,134 of the 50,140 in the country. It is followed by Galicia, with 21.5% of the hours in the last 10 years (10,785) despite having only 7.1% of the state's forest area. The Galician region has also needed special support this summer, with 405 interventions, 28.2% of the total, compared to 688 in Mañueco's territory.
The Ministry has 10 Brif bases, three of the nine in the peninsula are located in this community (León, Ávila and Soria). Some of these brigadistas assure that the Junta has such scarce own means because they assume that in case of difficulties they will have the material and human resources of these three units at their disposal. At the beginning of the summer, the association of forest firefighters of Castilla y León denounced that a fire in Cuéllar (Segovia) was controlled with aerial means of the ministry because the province did not have its own helicopter despite the autonomous law against fires.
Mañueco first defended the existing autonomic devices against fire but, as the crisis increased, he demanded more help from the State and criticized the fact that he did not receive it with the necessary speed. However, on several occasions these extra services provided by the Ministry were not used.
Spokesmen for the Environment of the Junta de Castilla y León claim that these means of the ministry "are at the disposal of the communities to be used when necessary" and that they "rigorously follow the established protocols and, if necessary, the support of these state resources is requested".
The Ministry of Environment recalls that they administer the largest community with the largest forest area and that they aspire to "forceful attacks in the first moments of a fire, which implies the mobilization of a significant number of means from the beginning". "Castilla y León assumes its competences in forest fires and provides the operative with the means it considers adequate, including complementary aerial resources," they emphasize, and recall that this competence over aerial firefighting means was reserved by the State.
Andalusia, with less forest area than Castilla y León (4.4 million hectares compared to 5.1 million) has 14 more aircraft. Castilla-La Mancha, with a million and a half less forest hectares than Castilla y León, has the same fire-fighting aircraft.

urn:contentItem:6GR0-D023-RV5F-V013-00000-00American Geophysical Union: Lightning to Spark More Wildfires in Western US in Coming Decades2025-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisAmerican Geophysical Union: Lightning to Spark More Wildfires in Western US in Coming DecadesTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

(TNSjou) -- The American Geophysical Union issued the following news release:

* * *

Lightning to spark more wildfires in western US in coming decades

New study finds increasing hot weather and lightning could spark more fires

*

Lightning will ignite more wildfires in the western United States in the coming decades as temperatures increase due to climate change, according to a new study that combined predictions for fire-friendly and lightning-friendly weather conditions.

In the western United States, lightning is responsible for more than two-thirds of the area burned by wildfires, and that number is only going to grow. Starting as early as 2031-2060, the study found essentially all of the western United States, or 98%, will see an increase in days posing a risk for lightning- started wildfires.

Areas that are already at high risk for wildfires started by lightning, such as Oregon, Idaho and Montana, are expected to see the largest increase in overall lightning days, with up to 12 more days per summer by 2060. Some areas, particularly in the U.S. Southwest, like Arizona, are expected to see a smaller increase as they will simply see less lightning.

The new study was published in Earth's Future, AGU's journal for interdisciplinary research on the past, present and future of our planet and its inhabitants.

"The first step was to project lightning," said Dmitri Kalashnikov, research scientist at the University of California Merced and lead author on the study. "The typical climate models don't directly simulate lightning. It's too small a process."

To get around this, Kalashnikov created his own machine-learning models that predict lightning based on the occurrence of weather variables that are typically found in climate models, such as the amount of moisture in the atmosphere. He published the models last year in AGU's Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres.

He combined his lightning models with the Fire Weather Index projections to predict the number of future days when conditions that encourage lightning and fire ignition and spread coincide.

The Canadian Forest Fire Weather Index, created in 1968, measures how favorable the weather is on a given day for wildfires. It keeps track of temperature, precipitation, humidity and other factors that could impact fires. For example, higher temperatures or lower precipitation, especially prolonged, can increase the chances of a fire.

While there have been previous models created for worldwide changes in lightning, Kalashnikov and his team created models that were specifically trained for locations in the western United States and for a closer timeframe. Their models focused on the years 2030 to 2060, compared to previous models that typically only looked at the end of the century.

Using the Fire Weather Index, researchers were able to predict how the number of days that have a high risk of wildfires will change over the coming decades.

The modeling found the northwestern United States was expected to see the largest increase in lightning days. Parts of Idaho, Oregon and Montana saw the largest increase in this cloud-to-ground lightning, or lightning that strikes the ground, which can ignite flammable vegetation. However, due to lesser increases in the Fire Weather Index, these areas will see slower increases in fire risk compared to areas farther south.

The southern half of the western United States still saw an increase in potential fires started by lightning, despite seeing a lower risk for lightning increases than the northern states. The increase is still projected because the entire West saw a general increase in high-risk days for wildfires as temperatures climb and the risk of droughts and heatwaves increase. In the south, Colorado, Wyoming, Arizona and New Mexico projected the largest increases in wildfires started by lightning.

Kalashnikov said next steps could expand what the models include, like bringing in rainfall amounts to differentiate between dry lightning and wet lightning, or lightning that happens with or without rain. This could help differentiate between thunderstorms that pose a risk of wildfires versus heavy-rain producing storms that could create flash flooding.

"You can't help but wonder what the future will look like, especially if you dig in and you realize that there's actually a lot that we don't understand," Kalashnikov said.

Notes for journalists:

This study is published in Earth's Future, an open-access AGU journal. View and download a pdf of the study here (https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2025EF006108). Neither this press release nor the study is under embargo.

Paper title:

"Projections of Lightning-Ignited Wildfire Risk in the Western United States"

Authors:

* Dmitri Kalashnikov, Sierra Nevada Research Institute, University of California, Merced, California, USA

* John Abatzoglou, Management of Complex Systems Department, University of California, Merced, California, USA

* Frances Davenport, Civil and Environmental Engineering, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado, USA

* Zachary Labe, NOAA OAR Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory, Princeton, New Jersey, USA

* Paul Loikith, Department of Geography, Portland State University, Portland, Oregon, USA

* Danielle Touma, Institute for Geophysics, University of Texas, Austin, Texas, USA

* Deepti Singh, School of the Environment, Washington State University, Vancouver, Washington, USA

* * *

AGU (www.agu.org) is a global community supporting more than half a million advocates and professionals in Earth and space sciences. Through broad and inclusive partnerships, AGU aims to advance discovery and solution science that accelerate knowledge and create solutions that are ethical, unbiased and respectful of communities and their values. Our programs include serving as a scholarly publisher, convening virtual and in-person events and providing career support. We live our values in everything we do, such as our net zero energy renovated building in Washington, D.C. and our Ethics and Equity Center, which fosters a diverse and inclusive geoscience community to ensure responsible conduct.

Al Jazeera and news agencies

August 20th, 2025 ( Al Jazeera English - Delivered by Newstex )

Strong winds have hampered efforts to contain unremitting wildfires that continue to spread in Spain despite lower temperatures, as the death toll in Portugal has climbed to three people after a man was killed while helping fight fires there along the Iberian Peninsula.

Firefighters, backed by troops and water-dropping aircraft, were battling 21 blazes in western Spain classified as 'operational level two', meaning they pose a direct threat to nearby communities, said Virginia Barcones, director general of emergency services on Wednesday.

'Temperatures have dropped, but strong gusts of wind continue to hinder firefighting efforts, and the lack of rain is not helping, though we hope that changes in the coming days,' she told a news conference.

Forecasters said winds were expected to ease later in the day, with higher humidity levels likely to help efforts. Rain was forecast in some fire-hit regions on Thursday.

Spain endured a 16-day heatwave that ended Monday, with temperatures having soared above 40 degrees Celsius (104F) in many regions. The heat-fuelled wildfires have killed four people.

Train service between Madrid and the northwestern region of Galicia - suspended on August 14 - would resume because 'tracks are now safe', railway operator Adif said.

The wildfires 'are being gradually brought under control,' said Al Jazeera's Sonia Gallego, reporting from the Galicia region at the site of 'a controlled fire that was deliberately set alight by firefighters here,' which is done 'to try to get the fire to change direction, to avoid it causing even more damage.'

Earlier in the day, firefighters 'set the fire and then used the wind, which was blowing in the opposite direction to where the crops were and the wood, in order to direct those blazes and for it to extinguish itself naturally,' said Gallego.

'Because one of the reasons these wildfires have been extremely serious this year is there have been very strong winds coupled with record-breaking heatwaves.'

Officials said many of the fires were sparked by lightning during dry storms, though arson is suspected in some cases.

Aircraft from Italy, the Netherlands, the Czech Republic and Slovenia have joined the firefighting effort.

Germany sent 60 firefighters and 24 vehicles, France deployed 66 firefighters and 23 vehicles, while Finland sent 26 firefighters.

Nearly 400,000 hectares (988,000 acres) have burned in Spain this year, according to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), surpassing the previous record of 306,000 hectares (756,000 acres) in 2022, the worst season since records began in 2006.

In Portugal, a man died in an accident involving construction equipment being used to contain the flames. He had worked for a company hired to help the northern municipality of Mirandela fight the fires, commander Paulo Santos of the National Civil Protection Authority (ANEPC) told the AFP news agency.

Approximately 15 people were also injured in Portugal - one critically - while fighting fires Tuesday near the central city of Sabugal, where two water-bombing aeroplanes sent by Sweden through the European Union's civil protection agency were deployed.

Crews were still battling four large fires on Wednesday morning, the most complex of which were raging in the north and centre of the country.

More than 2,600 firefighters have been deployed, supported by about 20 aircraft.

Since the start of the year, more than 261,000 hectares (645,000 acres) in Portugal have been destroyed by fires, according to the EFFIS, compared with 143,000 hectares (353,000 acres) in 2024.

The fires in Spain and Portugal have been fuelled by heatwaves and drought blamed on climate change. Lower humidity in the air, vegetation and soil makes it easier for wildfires to ignite and harder to control them once they start.

urn:contentItem:6GVP-BWK3-RS50-N3YX-00000-00Woolly Mammoth: An Artful Exploration of Time2025-09-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 1Woolly Mammoth: An Artful Exploration of TimeEmily Rutz

Image Credits: Emily Rutz

The true power of a painting is that it takes you somewhere else. When you look at the Mona Lisa, you don't notice the swatches of paint, layer upon layer. You see the woman. In an art gallery, you're looking at individual moments in time. You're looking at stories, you see the tree before the canvas. This is what Professor Kristopher Benedict did in his exhibition, "Woolly Mammoth," which I and a group of English majors had the honor of visiting with Dr. Eirini Panagiotidou, the chairwoman of the Ekphrasis Club that we were all a part of. 

Kristopher Benedict is an art professor at West Chester University, a father and resident of Delaware County. He completed the 12 paintings and 26 drawings that comprise this exhibition during a year-long sabbatical. Four of these paintings were also part of an art show he did in July.

The main theme of the exhibition is, "looking back at your past and unburying it," which made Benedict think back to his own childhood. "When I was a kid, my mom would take these night classes at the local community college, and there was a Mastodon skeleton in the lobby, and I would read a book or make drawings... while she was taking her classes. And I just had this image of... this Mastodon kind of skeleton." The Mastodon was Sugar the Mastodon, found in Sugarloaf, New York, and he found himself connected to it. 

Of course, there are no woolly mammoths or prehistoric creatures in any of the paintings - though Mastodons are one of Benedict's many inspirations, as someone who previously worked at the New York Museum of Natural History while on a previous sabbatical. The exhibition title is meant to be a broad metaphor. 

"A Woolly Mammoth is a catchy title," says Benedict. "It's like, if you're gonna have an album, you know, like you're a musician naming an album, you want it to be a little catchy." 

The real meaning of the title, however, is to represent the overarching scale of time and one's personal connection to it. The woolly mammoth is also similar to an artist living in a world where some art forms are seen as extinct or devalued. "The woolly mammoth is an interesting character, but it's... not super relevant, right?" Benedict remarks to the audience. "But you know, at the same time... you try to like, resuscitate them and they have unfrozen, you know, mammoth DNA, so maybe they'll clone them. I don't know. These things are on my mind, and I guess I don't have a real, quick, easy answer for it."

So we are met with nostalgia. We see a drawing of a mermaid, sitting on a giant seashell and blowing on a conch, reminiscent of hand-me-down storybooks from the 1930s. But there is always a catch: the shadows of the seashell look like a deadly spider, what a child could make out from patterns on a wall after the lights are turned off. It makes you wonder, is the mermaid calling for help? The first large painting we see upon entry, "Delco Twin," is of a house surrounded by autumn, the sun setting in the western hills. The sunlight makes one part of the house look vibrant, but the untouched side reveals the true color of the house is gray. It reminded me of "Monster House," a movie I watched as a child. It reminded me of Boo Radley's house in "To Kill a Mockingbird," fallen into reckless abandon and disrepair. To Benedict, it's reminiscent of a Hitchcock movie.

My favorite of the paintings is a large one of dressed up children walking through snow - aptly titled, "Kids in the Snow"- all dressed up as magi. The tree branches are hanging down from the weight of the snow, layered over with burlap, as many of his paintings are. The atmosphere gives off a solemn air as children masquerade as adults on a holy mission, with one child in the center holding a staff with a flash of bright red. I can sense that in the world of the painting, the costumes are haphazardly put together from hand me down materials, possibly by a mother. It's almost like they plan to leave their childhood behind.

Sometimes his paintings will start with an idea, but sometimes, they start with technique. They start with the color idea or the scale idea or the material idea. "I kind of see all the imagery as some kind of metaphor or analogy, or having some connection to this kind of story, of like, what does it mean to be an artist? How do you create?"

There was a large difference to him in working between the large paintings and the small drawings that he can just throw away upon making a mistake - though he loved having more time to focus on them. "In the past, drawings would be something that I would do kind of quickly as a study for a painting, right, or something that was sort of provisional that would lead to something else, but because I had more time... that just gave me superpowers when it came to drawing."

In contrast, the largeness of the paintings are what drive the entire piece. "When I'm painting something big, I want to capitalize on the visuality... there are really impactful things that can happen from it." He concentrates on making big shapes of color - focusing on "making something more extroverted and more visual happen"- followed by imagery.

All of the large paintings started with high saturated, acrylic washes, and then developed on their own before he found an imagery that would suffice. "Delco Twin" started out looking like a forest fire before he came up with the idea of the "weird, creepy house." The large paintings came to him almost naturally, with him completing each one within a few months, whereas paintings like those would take a year pre-sabbatical. According to him, the artist is not motivated by the imagery as much as the balancing act of all the skills and techniques that make a painting. 

Another theme of the gallery is, "the vagabond," the wanderer that has either gone extinct or changed form, depending on your perspective. The exhibition begins with an image of a hobo, modeled after the image on the word's wikipedia page. The hobo carries a stick with a bag connected to its end. The painting struck him and reminded him of the wanderer archetype. "There's something about the way that paintings become psychological for me, the use of color, the way the surface kind of works, the way the imagery kind of changes, that makes me reflect on this role of the artist as being a little bit outside of, you know... the community or part of the community."

One drawing of many, laying out on the table for onlookers to touch, depicts a homeless woman and her cat perching on her shoulder with a children's playground superimposed from behind. The shades of purple that make up the painting contrast with the yellow mural on the wall behind. Another purple drawing features the duality of a medieval vagabond with a woman reading outside of where he went to undergrad. All of this makes him think about his role as the artist contrasted with the role of the viewer. 

One of the large paintings, "Orange Plaza," is not orange at all, but in shades of green. It depicts a crowded mall with a glass ceiling and a blooming tree in the center surrounded by benches. In the forefront of the painting is a man walking past with a shopping bag - maybe a vagabond himself. It was named Orange Plaza because it was the name of a mall in Orange County, New York, where he grew up. He found a photo of the mall, which was popular in the '80s, and he thought back to a time where he used to visit the mall, dimly lit and blasting loud music. 

"They have a certain kind of atmosphere to them and they've gone extinct, you know, this was extinct in my time. By the time they opened up the fancier mall across town, this one was starting to go south... so these... interesting kind[s] of spaces that time forgot or jumped between different areas between paintings is something that I was sort of playing with in the show too."

But, he doesn't want to spell out all the themes for you. His favorite part of being an artist is resigning his say for the sake of keeping ambiguity. Though he is tempted with the idea of keeping full creative control, he will never tell you the full reason why he named the exhibition what it is. "I like the idea of the audience really determining... most of the meaning for themselves."

The exhibition will be available for viewing in the Knauer Art Gallery (Swope 120) through Oct. 10, and his art can also be viewed on his website.

Emily Rutz is a second year English major and French minor. ER1034711@wcupa.edu
