urn:contentItem:6GG8-M5R3-S05S-N0VB-00000-00Researchers from China Earthquake Administration Detail New Studies and Findings in the Area of Sensor Research (MEAC: A Multi-Scale Edge-Aware Convolution Module for Robust Infrared Small-Target Detection)2025-08-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY - SENSOR RESEARCHResearchers from China Earthquake Administration Detail New Studies and Findings in the Area of Sensor Research (MEAC: A Multi-Scale Edge-Aware Convolution Module for Robust Infrared Small-Target Detection)


2025 AUG 11 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Research findings on sensor research are discussed in a new report. According to news originating from Wuhan, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Infrared small-target detection remains a critical challenge in military reconnaissance, environmental monitoring, forest-fire prevention, and search-and-rescue operations, owing to the targets' extremely small size, sparse texture, low signal-to-noise ratio, and complex background interference. Traditional convolutional neural networks (CNNs) struggle to detect such weak, low-contrast objects due to their limited receptive fields and insufficient feature extraction capabilities."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from China Earthquake Administration: "To overcome these limitations, we propose a Multi-Scale Edge-Aware Convolution (MEAC) module that enhances feature representation for small infrared targets without increasing parameter count or computational cost. Specifically, MEAC fuses (1) original local features, (2) multi-scale context captured via dilated convolutions, and (3) high-contrast edge cues derived from differential Gaussian filters. After fusing these branches, channel and spatial attention mechanisms are applied to adaptively emphasize critical regions, further improving feature discrimination. The MEAC module is fully compatible with standard convolutional layers and can be seamlessly embedded into various network architectures. Extensive experiments on three public infrared small-target datasets (SIRSTD-UAVB, IRSTDv1, and IRSTD-1K) demonstrate that networks augmented with MEAC significantly outperform baseline models using standard convolutions. When compared to eleven mainstream convolution modules (ACmix, AKConv, DRConv, DSConv, LSKConv, MixConv, PConv, ODConv, GConv, and Involution), our method consistently achieves the highest detection accuracy and robustness. Experiments conducted across multiple versions, including YOLOv10, YOLOv11, and YOLOv12, as well as various network levels, demonstrate that the MEAC module achieves stable improvements in performance metrics while slightly increasing computational and parameter complexity."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "These results validate the MEAC module's significant advantages in enhancing the detection of small and weak objects and suppressing interference from complex backgrounds. These results validate MEAC's effectiveness in enhancing weak small-target detection and suppressing complex background noise, highlighting its strong generalization ability and practical application potential."
For more information on this research see: MEAC: A Multi-Scale Edge-Aware Convolution Module for Robust Infrared Small-Target Detection. Sensors, 2025,25(14):4442. (Sensors - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/sensors). The publisher for Sensors is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/s25144442.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Jinlong Hu, Institute of Seismology, China Earthquake Administration, Wuhan 430071, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Tian Zhang, Ming Zhao.
Keywords for this news article include: China Earthquake Administration, Wuhan, People's Republic of China, Asia, Sensor Research, Technology.

August 11th, 2025 ( VTDigger - Delivered by Newstex )

Map via Vermont Agency of Natural Resources

Most of the state was under a 'very high' fire risk warning as of Monday due to dry conditions, according to Vermont Emergency Management.

Only the central portion of the southern end of the state, including eastern Rutland and Bennington counties, and western Windsor and Windham counties, were under a lower-level 'high' risk, the department wrote in a Facebook post. It warned Vermonters to avoid open burning, exercise caution with outdoor grills, campfires and machinery, and properly extinguish cigarettes.

Megan Davin, a spokesperson for the Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation, said three 'very high' fire warnings had been issued so far in 2025. Meanwhile, there were 13 overall in 2024 and 13 in 2023.

Dan Dillner, the state forest fire supervisor, said the current conditions were abnormal compared to the past 20 years. 'I don't know what normal is anymore,' he said.

Wildfires are supposed to be less common in the summer, when the state is usually lush and green, but they appear to be popping up more frequently, he said. In July, the state spent weeks fighting an 11-acre wildfire in Fair Haven. The last time a wildfire of that size had broken out in July was in 1988.

He urged Vermonters to follow safe fire practices. Along with avoiding open burns, anyone lighting a grill or campfire should keep it away from vegetation, monitor the embers and make sure it's always attended. People also should be careful with cigarettes and other small burning items.

'When you get to 'very high' fire danger, even flicking a cigarette into brush can cause a fire,' he said.

Forty-five wildfires have been reported in Vermont so far this year, totaling 46 acres of damage. One was attributed to a lightning strike. The rest? Human-caused.

'We in the Northeast need to remember our Smokey the Bear,' the famous mascot for fire safety, he said.

Burlington drier than normal so far this summer

The alert came as the state entered a new phase of hotter temperatures in an already hotter-than-average summer. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory for Chittenden, Franklin, Grand Isle and western Addison counties for Monday and Tuesday. Burlington is expected to reach temperatures in the mid-90s on both days, the weather service said.

The Vermont Department of Health maintains a list of cooling centers across the state and tips on staying safe in the heat on its website.

Recent days have also seen less rain than expected for this time of year. Burlington has received 6 inches of rain in total since June 1, the start of meteorological summer. By contrast, the average rainfall during that time between 1990 and 2020 was over 9 inches.

Roughly three-quarters of Vermont has been reported to have 'abnormally dry' conditions by the U.S. Drought Monitor, a research project from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.

Read the story on VTDigger here: Vermont reaches 'very high' fire risk amid hot, dry conditions.

urn:contentItem:6FCJ-TMY3-S63G-B04F-00000-00Findings from Nanjing Forestry University Has Provided New Data on Machine Learning (A Forest Fire Prediction Framework Based On Multiple Machine Learning Models)2025-03-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisMACHINE LEARNINGFindings from Nanjing Forestry University Has Provided New Data on Machine Learning (A Forest Fire Prediction Framework Based On Multiple Machine Learning Models)


2025 MAR 20 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Disease Prevention Daily -- A new study on Machine Learning is now available. According to news reporting originating in Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Fire risk prediction is of great importance for fire prevention. Fire risk maps are an effective tool to quantify regional fire risk."


Financial support for this research came from Start-up Fund for New Talented Researchers of Nanjing Vocational University of Industry Technology.
The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing Forestry University, "Most existing studies on forest fire risk maps mainly use a single machine learning model, but different models have varying degrees of feature extraction in the same spatial environment, leading to inconsistencies in prediction accuracy. To address this issue, this study proposes a novel integrated machine learning framework that systematically evaluates multiple models and combines their outputs through a weighted ensemble approach, thereby enhancing prediction robustness. During the feature selection stage, factors including socio-economic, climate, terrain, remote sensing data, and human factors were considered. Unlike previous studies that mainly use a single model, eight models were evaluated and compared using performance metrics. Three models were weighted based on Mean Squared Error (MSE) values, and cross-validation results showed an improvement in model performance. The integrated model achieved an accuracy of 0.8602, an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.772, and superior sensitivity (0.9234), outperforming individual models. Finally, the weighted framework was applied to generate a fire risk map."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Compared with prior studies, this multi-model ensemble approach not only improves predictive accuracy but also provides a scalable and adaptable framework for fire risk mapping, and provides valuable insights to address future fire sustainability issues."
For more information on this research see: A Forest Fire Prediction Framework Based On Multiple Machine Learning Models. Forests, 2025;16(2):329. Forests can be contacted at: Mdpi, St Alban-Anlage 66, Ch-4052 Basel, Switzerland.
Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Fuquan Zhang, Nanjing Forestry University, Coll Informat Sci & Technol & Artificial Intellige, Nanjing 210037, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Chen Wang, Yiqing Xu and Hanze Liu.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.3390/f16020329. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Nanjing, People's Republic of China, Asia, Cyborgs, Emerging Technologies, Machine Learning, Nanjing Forestry University.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2025, NewsRx LLC

urn:contentItem:6GKF-KX73-RTM6-C19X-00000-00Alarm due to strong winds in Ica: This is how this event was experienced at the beginning of August| Videos2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisAlarm due to strong winds in Ica: This is how this event was experienced at the beginning of August| Videos


The National Meteorology and Hydrology Service (Senamhi) reported that the strong winds that caused material damages last Thursday in the central and southern coast of the country will continue until this Sunday, although another dust and sand storm like the one that alarmed the population of Ica and Arequipa is ruled out.


The winds, whose speeds reached up to 43 km/h, left 26 families affected and three victims in the department of Ica alone. In addition, there were power and telephone outages, the suspension of all tourist activities, as well as material damage to 28 houses with tin roofs and wooden and plywood modules. In Tacna, meanwhile, 115 houses and 40 hectares of corn crops were reported affected.
According to the Senamhi weather warning, the increase in wind speed will reach "orange level" for today, with speeds close to 32 km/h on the north coast, around 40 km/h on the central coast, close to 22 km/h on the south coast and values close to 44 km/h on the coast of Ica. This increase could generate cloud cover, fog and scattered drizzle, especially at night and in the morning.
Although these are higher values than those recorded in recent days, Ricardo Rosas Luján, Senamhi director of Ica, considered it unlikely that dust and sand will rise again in the magnitude recorded on Thursday. "The cause of this unusual phenomenon has occurred because the anticyclone, once it approaches the Pacific, brings fast winds and, due to the warming of the ground, has raised yellow and reddish dust, especially in Nasca and Palpa," he said.
Rosas attributes deforestation as one of the reasons for the dust lifting has been so intense. "August is the month of the Paraca due to the pressure gradients that occur between winter and spring. There is so much dust lifting because, unfortunately those areas 10 years ago were native plant forests and now there are no more," he added.
While the strong winds are affecting the coast, 18 regions of the Peruvian highlands and jungle are under a forest fire warning. For Huancavelica, Ayacucho, Apurímac, Arequipa, Moquegua, Cusco, Puno and Tacna this warning is at "red" level.
According to Senamhi, atmospheric conditions that could favor the occurrence and spread of these fires, with moderate to extreme intensity levels, will last until Monday, August 4.
"The absence of precipitation in these regions is expected to continue, as well as a decrease in humidity and an increase in daytime temperature," they indicated.
The third event warned for this weekend is light to moderate swells. Yesterday, 61 ports of the central and southern coast of the country were closed due to the warning of the Directorate of Hydrography and Navigation (DHN) of the Peruvian Navy.
"These swells will be present in our coastline until Sunday, August 3 and will have greater impact in areas that have open or semi-open beaches, so it is recommended to regional and local governments, Port Captaincies and companies of the aquatic community to take preventive measures to avoid accidents and personal or material damage," they said in a statement.
It is considered light swell when the sea presents waves with heights up to 50% more than its normal characteristics, while in moderate intensity the height of the waves can reach up to double its normal conditions.
In this context, yesterday 50 containers were reported to have fallen into the sea from a Taiwanese-flagged merchant vessel at the Port of Callao, which caused the partial closure of this maritime terminal for several hours. The Everunar vessel, with an estimated capacity of 7,000 containers, was anchored in the bay of Callao, in the waiting area to enter the port terminal, when the incident occurred at 10:30 am.
According to Captain Amilcar Velásquez, Captain of the Port of Callao, the incident was not caused by the abnormal swell. The causes are under investigation. "The merchandise is not dangerous or polluting to the sea. The time it will take to recover the containers will be 15 to 20 days, but it is not in the transit channel of entry and exit to the port", he told Canal N.

urn:contentItem:6GGV-PHF3-RW2W-G361-00000-00Families see fun side of law enforcement at Community Night Out2025-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSFamilies see fun side of law enforcement at Community Night OutHYUN SOO LEERepublican & Herald, Pottsville, Pa.

ASHLAND — Crowds turned out to Memorial Field on Tuesday to mingle with their neighborhood heroes as part of the borough’s Community Night Out event.

Firefighters, law enforcement and EMS were all represented at the second annual edition of the event, Ashland’s version of National Night Out.

Both borough fire companies were in attendance — Washington and American Hose — as were several local police officers and members of the Schuylkill County Sheriff’s Office, among other agencies.

The event included a “Touch-a-Truck” experience, allowing kids to interact with vehicles staged around the park. Youngsters beamed as they sat behind the wheel of fire trucks and patrol vehicles, posing for pictures and perhaps conceiving of future careers.

Jayce Mckillips, 3, of Ashland pretends to drive a firetruck during Community Night Out at Memorial Field in Ashland, Tuesday, Aug. 12, 2025. (MATTHEW PERSCHALL/MULTIMEDIA EDITOR)

M&T Bank volunteers pose with the Mrs. T’s Pierogies mascot during Community Night Out at Memorial Field in Ashland, Tuesday, Aug. 12, 2025. (MATTHEW PERSCHALL/MULTIMEDIA EDITOR)

Caden Lally, 2, of St. Clair enjoys the bounce house during Community Night Out at Memorial Field in Ashland, Tuesday, Aug. 12, 2025. (MATTHEW PERSCHALL/MULTIMEDIA EDITOR)

Families enjoy Community Night Out at Memorial Field in Ashland, Tuesday, Aug. 12, 2025. (MATTHEW PERSCHALL/MULTIMEDIA EDITOR)

Caden Lally, 2, of St. Clair enjoys the bounce house during Community Night Out at Memorial Field in Ashland, Tuesday, Aug. 12, 2025. (MATTHEW PERSCHALL/MULTIMEDIA EDITOR)

Show Caption

1 of 5

Jayce Mckillips, 3, of Ashland pretends to drive a firetruck during Community Night Out at Memorial Field in Ashland, Tuesday, Aug. 12, 2025. (MATTHEW PERSCHALL/MULTIMEDIA EDITOR)

Expand

Ashland Police Chief Gerard Daley said the event is important to the community, given the shortage of police officers across the country.

“Everybody is struggling to find police officers,” he said. “Nobody wants to do the job anymore.”

The borough currently has three full-time officers and three part-timers, he said.

Daley said events like Community Night Out allow people to see a different side of their local police force.

“It’s great because they get to meet people, and see people not in a firefighter capacity or a police capacity,” he said. “It’s more as a community, and the citizens just (get) to interact with everyone.”

He said the borough had previously held its National Night Out in downtown Ashland, but it was canceled after the COVID-19 pandemic.

Last year, Daley, then-Fire Chief Phillip Groody and Assistant Fire Chief Charlie Orth decided to put together a Community Night Out on Memorial Field, which provided a much bigger space for all the agencies involved.

“We kind of incorporated everything in one event,” Daley said. “We have the room, and we get a ton of people. Great turnout both years.”

Ed Gough, vice president of the American Hose Co. No.1, said the event has been warmly welcomed by local residents.

“It’s important for the community to get out and see what we’re all about,” he said.

The event also included people from the Schuylkill County Emergency Management Agency, Pennsylvania Canine Search and Rescue, Washington Fire Company Ambulance, borough fire police and the state Forest Fire Wardens. There were also local civic and youth organizations and businesses, including Famous Reading Outdoors.

urn:contentItem:6GR7-VP53-RSMG-X0PJ-00000-00Conserving indigenous territories could also protect human health2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:51:48ZLexisNexisConserving indigenous territories could also protect human health


A new study shows the influence of indigenous territories in the Amazon on human health. The results, although they vary depending on the state of the landscape and whether these areas are legally recognized or not, showed that they can contribute to reducing fire-related and zoonotic diseases.


"Everyone says tropical forests are the lungs of the world, but we should really call them the immune system." That was the phrase that stuck with Paula Prist, coordinator of the Forestry and Grasslands Programme of the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), during a conversation with a journalist. For years, the Brazilian biologist, with a PhD in Ecology, began to investigate how changes in this type of landscape have impacted human health.
Gradually, however, she became interested in possible solutions to this phenomenon, beyond understanding its drivers. "We know more about what's leading to these health problems, but we're not really trying to understand how we can solve them," Prist tells this newspaper. It was that motivation that led her to lead an international, interdisciplinary group of researchers, which just published a paper in the group's journal , .
The study focused on Indigenous Territories (IT) in the Amazon, which, although known to be crucial for biodiversity conservation, have been much less studied in relation to their role in human health. This is why the scientists used data from the last 20 years on health indicators in the region and assessed the influence of ITs in this area, taking into account the characteristics of their environment and their legal status.
The data collected covered human cases, in municipalities or similar scales in most Amazonian countries, of 21 fire-associated diseases (cardiovascular and respiratory) and six vector-borne zoonotic diseases (malaria, cutaneous and visceral leishmaniasis, Chagas disease, hantavirus, and spotted fever).
Ana Filipa Palmeirim, a Brazilian ecologist, professor at the Federal University of Pará and co-author of the study, begins by clarifying that the findings of this research were not linear or homogeneous. "It's quite complex," says the professor. "We analyzed it that way; accounting for all the synergies and interactions between the quantity and quality of forests, as well as their configuration. We found different results depending on the context and this varied for each disease."
On the one hand, Palmeirim talks about forest fire-related diseases, which can be triggered by inhaling pollutants in the air. Fire smoke has been associated with increased respiratory symptoms, heart disease, stroke, bronchitis, asthma, lung cancer, among others. This has been the case in the Amazon, where the number of people hospitalized with respiratory system diseases has increased.
"For example, in the Brazilian Amazon, it is estimated that for every kilogram increase in PM 2.5 (tiny particles, 2.5 micrometers or less), there are more than 24 new cases of fire-related diseases, while between 2002 and 2011, deforestation fires were responsible, on average, for 2,906 premature deaths from cardiopulmonary diseases and lung cancer," the article reads.
And what do the Indigenous Territories have to do with it? Palmeirim says that she and her team found that ITs have the capacity to mitigate the impacts of PM 2.5 on diseases associated with forest fires, as long as their surroundings or neighboring municipalities have a high forest cover of more than 45%.
Specifically, for cardiovascular (heart and circulation) diseases, this effect can only occur in municipalities with a low edge density, i.e., where the forest is continuous and almost no deforestation patches are found. In fact, scientists point out that the fragmentation of these ecosystems can be very harmful to human health.
On the other hand, when we think of zoonotic diseases, "the story is different and quite complex because it depends on the disease, human contact and also on the quality of the forest," says Professor Palmeirim. One of the findings of the study is that when the forest area outside ITs has a lower edge density (low fragmentation), zoonotic diseases may increase, because there may be more habitat for vectors, such as mosquitoes. In sum, when ITs are less extensive and outside them there is more forest cover, the incidence of these diseases seems to increase, as people would be more exposed at the forest edges.
However, the scientists found that when the forest covers 40% of a municipality, both inside and outside the Indigenous Territories, this risk may decrease. Although further research is still needed, several studies have indicated that this threshold is key to a balance in ecosystems, where pathogens would be distributed among different species and not concentrated in just a few.
"Indigenous Territories generally buffer deforestation and therefore help maintain biodiversity and overall ecological stability," the study asserts. "These conditions give these areas the potential to minimize disease outbreaks." The experts also highlighted the influence of legal recognition of Indigenous Territories.
Victoria Morpurgo-Dest, a biomedical and health scientist who also participated in the study, highlights a finding on this topic: "Legally recognized ITs are associated with better community health outcomes and greater resilience, demonstrating how territorial management and health are deeply connected. In contrast, in ITs that do not have this status, the incidence of fire-related diseases would increase, probably due to higher burning activity and deforestation rates, as observed in the Brazilian Amazon.
In this sense, the Venezuelan biologist and co-author of the study, Adrian David González, stresses the importance of updating land use planning and legally recognizing ITs, not only to contain deforestation, but also for the sake of health.
It is worth mentioning that the scientists recognize the limitations of their work. One of them, for example, was that each country has its own way of reporting diseases. However, Gonzalez emphasizes that in the Amazon "a general pattern is evident" and that despite the different realities of the countries "we share a common territory, with transboundary effects".
"Our findings highlight the complex interaction between conservation and human health, determined by local contexts and the legal recognition of Indigenous Territories. They also underscore the critical role of forests managed by indigenous peoples as protective barriers, helping to mitigate the emergence and re-emergence of infectious diseases, including those linked to climate-related impacts," says ecologist and epidemiologist Maria Eugenia Grillet, another researcher.
Prist, the leader of this team, hopes that her study will contribute to a better understanding of the complex relationships between indigenous territories and the Amazon. In her eyes, the water and climate function of this tropical rainforest, the largest in the world, is not entirely tangible to the public. "But when we talk about human health, it's our individual feeling, so I think this can be useful for people to understand the importance of conservation."

SECTION 2 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

2.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

Weyerhaeuser Company has consistently demonstrated its commitment to sustainable forestry and community development through strategic investments and philanthropic efforts. Recently, Weyerhaeuser made headlines with its land donation for the Row River wildfire substation, exemplifying its leadership in wildfire protection and emergency services partnerships. This initiative underscores Weyerhaeuser's dedication to wildfire mitigation and response infrastructure, crucial in safeguarding forests and nearby communities.

In West Virginia, Weyerhaeuser's investment strategy is robust, epitomized by a $1 million community investment in Buckhannon. This investment is set to bolster rural economic development and enhance Weyerhaeuser's community grants and support efforts. Highlighting its philanthropic endeavors, Weyerhaeuser's charitable giving focuses on corporate social responsibility, revered by the Buckhannon community for fostering sustainable forestry.

Through such initiatives, including timberland and forestland donations, Weyerhaeuser maintains a steadfast commitment to land stewardship, enhancing community resilience, and ensuring a sustainable future for generations. Weyerhaeuser's overarching goal remains clear: elevating community development while ensuring the sustainability of critical ecosystems.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

SECTION 5 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.
